title: GitHub - hackclub/toriel: ğŸ‘‹ A friendly bot that assists new members with joining Hack Club
content:
We read every piece of feedback, and take your input very seriously.
To see all available qualifiers, see ourdocumentation.
ğŸ‘‹ A friendly bot that assists new members with joining Hack Club

Toriel is currently undergoing a new revamp! You can view the stuff being worked onhere, and take part in #toriel-dev, if you're on the slack
Just a lil' ol greeter bot to direct new members joining the Hack Club Slack. You wonder what she might say...
Toriel is a fork ofClippy.
Contributions are encouraged and welcome!
In order to run Toriel locally, you'll need tojoin the Hack Club Slack. From there, ask @creds to be added to the Toriel app on Slack.
Clone this repositorygit clone https://github.com/hackclub/toriel && cd toriel
Installngrok(if you haven't already)
Install dependenciesnpm install
Create.envfile
Start servernpm run dev
Forward your local server tounderpass, an open source alternative made by a Hack Club team member.
Update the settings in themanifest.yml
Update slash commands
Go toapi.slack.comto create a new slack app
Click "Install to Workspace" under the "Basic Information" tab in the settings bar
Edit the env variables in.envfile.
whereSIGNING_SECRETis your app's Signing Secret, which you can find by clicking on "Basic Information" in the settings bar and scrolling down (click show to and copy it)andBot_User_OAuth_Tokenis found under "OAuth & Permissions" (You will need click "Install to Workspace" before you can view the token)
Create a private channelwhere your app can run the welcome flow. Similar to the role that #in-the-cave plays for Toriel (runtoriel-restartin slack to see what this means).
Edittranscript.yml. If you want to make your own local transcript.yml with your own channels for testing, call ittranscript.dev.yaml, and it will load from that instead, however, it won't be synced to production.

You can add your own bot to these channels for testingoryou can delete or comment out channels you don't need for testing
IMPORTANT: you might need access to these channels later on, like to add anew user to channels, which means not giving your bot access now could break the app.
Add your own private channel to the channel list. For example, if your channel ismsw-test-cavewith the channel idCDF1A5EG865, you would add:
You can find the channel ID by opening the channel and clicking on the channel name in the top left. Scroll down the modal and you should see it in the bottom left corner
Do a global find and replace in the codebase to updatechannels.cavetochannels.name-of-your-private-channel
Runnpm run devagain and also reinstall your app to the workspace (under Basic Information)
If you run into an error where the message readsToriel is not invited to these channelsorchannel_not_found, just invite your bot to that channel (you can check the channel with its ID by referring back totranscript.yml. If the channel is private, you can create a new private channel as its substitute, but remember to update the references in the code. Ex.#toriels-diaryis a private channel, so you can create#msw-toriels-diary, add it totranscript.yml, and change all{channels.toriels-diary}to{channels.msw-toriels-diary}.
Note: you have to re-update the Underpass tunnel URL on the Slack app manifest and verify the URL each time to restart the server, since the tunnel URL changes
Formattingis important, please runnpm run fmton contribution.

title: A Home for High School Hackers â€“ Hack Club
content:
We are55,056teen hackersteen hackersfrom around the world who code together
Every day, thousands of HackÂ Clubbers gather online and in-person to make things with code. Whether youâ€™re a beginner programmer or have years of experience, thereâ€™s a place for you at HackÂ Club. Read about ourhacker ethic.
Connect with other teenage codersHave a coding question? Looking for project feedback? Youâ€™ll find hundreds of fabulous people to talk to in our globalSlack(like Discord), active at all hours.
Build open source learning toolsWe build large open source projects together (3k+Â PRs a year) like this website, a game engine, daily streak system, and more!
Gather IRL with other makersMeet other HackÂ Clubbers in your community to build together at one of the 400+HackÂ Clubsandhigh school hackathons.
We gather both online and in-person to share our love of code and make things together!
Build personal projects. Get free stuff.Oct 30 - Jan 31

30 Hack Clubbers went on a 7 day hike along the Pacific Crest Trail supplied by only the technical equipment that they built.
Coding doesnâ€™t have to be a solitary activity. At HackÂ Club, we make remarkable things together, and in our Slack youâ€™ll find awesome people to hang out with too. Code together, find your programming community, dream up something wild, or just #lounge.
Occasionally we invite someone we really want to speak to (like Sal Khan, George Hotz, and Lady Ada) and host anAMAwith them.
In collaboration with engineers on the HackÂ Club team, Hack Clubbers build learning tools for each other. Get involved with these projects by building something with our tools or contribute to the tools themselves.

SineRider is a game about love and graphing, powered by teenage hackers of all kinds: artists, musicians, programmers, storytellersâ€¦ so if thatâ€™s you, come join us! We can always use help keeping everything up to date and running smoothly.

Play your own Sprig games on this console, which you can assemble and disassemble. Each kit includes parts needed for getting started with hardware engineering and embedded systems programming.

title: Evergreen: Seattle Day of Service
content:
A Hackathon is a social coding eventâ€”and Days of Service is Hack Club's initiative to support girls learning to code by hosting gender-focused Hackathons as an opportunity for girls to build awesome projects!
Working with local youth organizations, high school Hack Club leaders run one-day coding events (a day of service) that help girls and gender minorities write their first lines of code. They might build their first ever website, video game, application, or even code a robot arm to draw out their sketches!
Built for beginners learning to code, girls are supported by experienced Hack Clubbers. By the end of the day, every single participant builds something with code. In 2023, Hack Club girls ran Days of Service in 6 cities, and in 2024 they'll increase events to more than 10 cities.
A track is a series of workshops for a specific coding subject that you will learn about during the hackathon!
In this workshop, participants will learn to create computer-generated art by drawing assorted shapes from our guides. They'll useBlot, a robotic arm created by Hack Club that translates code to creation. With this track, attendees will learn JavaScript and digitial fabrication. Afterwards, they'll be shipped their own robot arm to draw what they've created!
In this workshop, participants will learn the fundamentals of circuit board design with Hack Club'sOnBoard program. They'll useEasyEDA, a circuit design software, to complete this. Attendees will learn to use that software as well as the basics of PCB design. After students complete this track, they'll be shipped their PCB to have a physical copy of their creation!
In this workshop, participants learn the fundamentals of 3D modeling by building their own 3D village. They'll useSpline, a web-based 3D design tool, to accomplish this. Spline allows them to add interactivity and customize their design. With this track, attendees learn the basics of working in 3D, which can be used for websites, games, animation, and printing!
Attendance is free thanks to Hack Club's support!
Evergreen is a Days of Service event that aims to teach teens how to code and build their own projects.
That's perfectly okay! We will have workshops to teach you!
You should bring a laptop, but we will have Chromebooks available if you don't have a laptop.
You can work by yourself or in a team! The goal is to create something that you're proud of.
Evergreen will take place at the Amazon HQ in Seattle.
That's totally okay! Any high schooler can attend.
No worries! Contactnila@hackclub.comwith any questions you may have.

title: GitHub - hackclub/middleman
content:
We read every piece of feedback, and take your input very seriously.
To see all available qualifiers, see ourdocumentation.
At Hack Club, we use airtable a lot. Sometimes it's hard to keep track of which apps are making calls to airtable, and consuming the global airtable ratelimit. A common problem we run into is that one of our apps start to hit the limit with faulty retry logic, then bottleneck all of our services at once.
Middleman is a way to pipe all of our airtable requests through one location so we can track which apps are the most noisy.
Here's how you use it:
You can just swap out your calls fromhttps://api.airtable.com/v0/apitohttps://middleman.hackclub.com/airtable/v0/api. For example:
Please also set yourUser-Agentto something specific to your app! The whole point of this is to hunt down apps that are having trouble and we can't do that if we can't tell who you are!
Airtable.js's persistent retry logic is why we built this in the first place, so we don't really recommend using it. If you must though, it already has some built-in ways to handle this.
You can just setAIRTABLE_ENDPOINT_URL="https://middleman.hackclub.com/airtable"
We deploy using fly.io using ourGitHub action. This means anything pushed to main will automatically make & deploy a new build. Use this knowledge wisely.

title: Counterspell Manila
content:
A BEGINNER FRIENDLY GAME JAM
NOVEMBER 23-24, 2024 â€¢ MANILA
Counterspell Manila is a beginner friendly game jam for high schoolers happening in Manila whereartists, musicians, and codersget together to build apps and games.
Build whatever you want!
Any game counts! The theme for Counterspell Manila will be decided through peer voting before the event starts.
Whether youâ€™re a beginner or experienced in programming- weâ€™ll have workshops, resources and mentors throughout the 12 hours to help you with your project.
Artist, Musician or Coder?
Join one of threeguildswhen you sign up!
You can join the guild you identify with for exclusive swag and badges! You also get to compete against other guilds in friendly activities/challenges throughout Counterspell Manila!
How does agame jamwork?
Sign up for Counterspell Manila
Find a team of other teenagers at Counterspell
Start building your game (no experience needed)
Attend workshops, or talk to one of our mentors for help
Ship what you made and share it with the rest of the world!
Counterspell Manila will go on for12 hours
Here's a rough schedule so you know what to expect!
Doors open
11:00 AM
Opening ceremony
12:00 PM
Lunch
12:30 PM
Start working on your game!
1:00 PM
Gamedev workshop 1
2:00 PM

4:00 PM

Midnight surprise

Can't make it to Manila?
There are 200+ other Counterspell locations worldwide!
Boston, MA
New York City, NY
Ottawa, ON
Basking Ridge, NJ
Austin, TX
San Francisco, CA
Burlington, VT
Oshkosh, WI
Counterspell Manila is organized by teenagers, for teenagers.
Organize a Counterspell event in your city.Sign up.
Get notified when registrations open
Frequently Asked Questions
Am I eligible to sign up?
If you're 18 or under, yes, we are so excited to see you! If you're over 18 but
        still in high school, shoot us an email atcounterspell@hackclub.com.
Does participating cost anything?
It's entirely free! We'll have meals, snacks, and beverages onsite at the hackathon, as well as swag, prizes, and fun mini-events.
What has Hack Club done before?
We have run multiple events around the world. The summer of '21, wechartered a train across Americaand ran the world's longest hackathon on land. Last year, we ran an outdoors do-it-yourselfcamping 
        adventurein Cabot, Vermont.
I'm not good at coding, can I join?
This hackathon is for hackers of all skill levels! We'll have workshops and other events so join us and let's learn together. If you'd like to start exploring some introductory projects, check outHack Club Workshops.
What can I make at Counterspell?
At Counterspell, we're building video games of all kinds! The theme will be revealed at the start of the hackathon.
What do I need to bring to Counterspell?
Your laptop, charger, and an open mind! If your location is overnight, also bring toiletries, and a sleeping bag.
My parents are worried!
We're here to help! Ask them to reach out to us atcounterspell@hackclub.comand we'll make sure to answer all their questions!
How can I reach out for more questions?
Contact us! Reach out at#counterspellon the Hack Club Slack or email us atcounterspell@hackclub.com.
          We're always ready to answer all your questions!
Built with love by teenagers, for teenagers at Hack Club
Counterspell Manila Organizer:Carl Louise Romales (17, Manila)

title: HCB Blog
content:
We're working on making detailed transaction information available to you all; incoming ACH transfers now include details about who sent the ACH:
And, if an international wire is returned, we're now surfacing the return reason.
Hope this helps you all navigate the complex financial world!
Ever had a sponsor pay an invoice by check? It's awkward because then you're stuck with an "unpaid" invoice on HCB.
You can now mark invoices as paid if a sponsor pays using alternative means (check, cash, etc.):
We're experimenting with something new - drop in an invoice to the ACH or check form and HCB will do itâ€™s best to autofill any fields.
Try it out and let us know what you think.
HCB's donation page is a great way to raise money for your organization. With one click, you can share a link to your donation page on social media, in emails, or on your website. It's incredibly versatile, but how do you know which platforms perform best?
Starting today, you can analyze which website referred your donors, and, for more granular insights, theUTM parametersof the link they clicked. This data is available on the transaction details page for all donations with referrer data.
Hopefully this feature will help you understand where your donors are coming from and how to better reach them in the future!
Right now, HCB's login page is a little boring. It gets the job done, but it's by no means exciting. That's why we're thrilled to unveil our refreshed login experience!
It features a sleek, intuitive design and now includes a gallery of handpicked images from iconic organizations running on HCB. Plus, it provides some insight into what HCB is all about.
We're hoping the new design improves your experience on HCB and we're always happy to hear feedback.

Today we're launching a new way to stay up-to-date on HCB: our new blog.
For as long as I can remember, HCB has been usingÂ HeadwayÂ to announce product updates and changes to users, but over time our needs have shifted. Along with changelog updates, we want to share more content online, like engineering deep-dives, our monthly newsletters, and more.
With this change, all of our posts are now open source and available onÂ GitHubÂ as well.
We're excited to share more with you in the future. Stay tuned!
For a long time, HCB cards appeared as a mysterious, dark, unbranded card in your Apple Wallet.
Today, we're excited to announce that it's getting a new look! Some people might say it's fresh & crisp, just like a juicy apple ğŸ. Enjoy!
Thanks to Ian and Sam for the design work!
Exciting news for organizations doing work outside the US! HCB now supports sending money to overseas bank accounts via an international wire:
To send an international wire, you'll need your recipient's bank's SWIFT code and account number as well as some country-specific information. Once you've got that, it's just like sending an ACH transfer to a US bank account on HCB.
Unfortunately, wires are expensive to send. Our partner bank charges us $25 per wire; therefore, to keep HCB sustainable without passing this fee onto you, each wire sent must be at least $500. We've waived this requirement for organizations that have raised over $50k.
If you have any feedback on this wires feature, we'd love to hear from you! We're always looking to improve our product, and wires has been a difficult feature to polish.
When we need help from you, we want to make sure we're reaching out to the right people.
By default, we'll email everyone who is a part of your team on HCB. However, if you have a shared team email or would prefer for us to reach out to a specific email, you can now let us know.
Hack Club launched High Seas! This is the largest Hack Club event ever, having already reached more than 1.5 million teenagers around the world. High Seas empowers teenagers to build projects, share them, and collectDoubloonswhich can be redeemed for amazing prizes.
Like all Hack Club initiatives, High Seas is open source and has transparent finances with HCB!
Until January 31st, we will send you free stuff just for coding. Here's how it works:
1.Â BUILD!Â Ship personal coding projects to earn Doubloons2.Â BATTLE!Â Ships compete for bonuses in peer-voted 1v1 matchups3.Â BOOTY!Â Exchange your Doubloons for cool stuff in the shop4.Â REPEAT!Â Build, battle, and booty it up until January 31st
To learn more and get involved, click here!
If you have feedback or feature requests, I'd love to hear them. Let me know your number one complaint about HCB by replying to this email.
All the best,
Dylan & the HCB Team

Transparency Mode has been one of HCB's flagship features for years. It revolutionized nonprofit financial transparency and allowed donors and the public to see how an organization utilizes funds. Upload a receipt to a transaction.
Click the purple AI button to generate a memo.
Accept the suggestions by clicking the checkmark or pressingÂ [enter].

You'll also notice that the receipt sidebar now includes some extracted information that provides a glanceable overview of the receipt's contents.

In the dark days of HCB, inviting people to your organization was always a binary risk assessment - "do I give this person unfettered access to everything, or nothing at all?"
Once we realized this was Suboptimal And A Bit Dangerousâ„¢ï¸, we started to think about operational security from users' perspectives more carefully.
User roleswas step one. This introduced predetermined permission sets to control users' access in an organization.
Today,we're introducing spending controls. This allows managers of HCB organizations to impose a finer level of control on how much money a member can spend.
To get to a team member's spending controls page, visit the Team page and click on the$icon next to their name.
A team member's spending controls page gives you consolidated details of how they're using their cards.
When controls are disabled, a member can spend any amount of money with their cards. (Since they're not managers, so still can't transfer via ACH, check, HCB transfer, etc.)
With spending controls enabled, new transactions on Fiona's card will be approved/declined based on Fiona's balance. Since we haven't given her an allowance yet, her balance is zero! (as seen above)
Hint: click theNewbutton on the top right.
Now that I've given Fiona an allowance, she can spend it with her card! This $2,500 didn't leave the organization's balance when I created an allowance. Instead, both balances will decrease when she makes a purchase.
You should probably also know that these allowances are not time-dependent. They don't expire, and they do not recur (it's not a weekly/monthly limit).
As a convenience, you can also choose to enable spending controls and set an initial amount when you invite someone to your organization.

Starting today, in addition to a CSV or JSON file, you can now export your transaction into a Ledger file for use with theLedger CLI.
You may be wondering, what's the backstory behind Ledger? Five years ago, Hack Club HQ used Ledger to keep track of and open source all it's finances:https://github.com/hackclub/ledger. It became too much to maintain. When HQ itself began using HCB, we built Transparency Mode so that we could continue open sourcing our finances. That said, Ledger still is awesome. So now, if you'd like to use the Ledger CLI and are on HCB, you can export your transactions to the.ledgerfile format and have fun exploring your money in the terminal!
Additionally, you can also export the transactions of organisations with Transparency Mode enabled, check out HQ's finances:https://hcb.hackclub.com/exports/hq.ledger.

We're excited to share that Hack Club Bank now has an official public API.
TheHack Club Bank APIis a read-only, unauthenticated REST API which enables you to read public information from organizations withTransparency Modeenabled. This includes transaction history like checks, ACHs, invoices, transfers, donations, as well as organizations and their respective team members.
This API will pave the way for more applications likeSlack Club Bank,HackPenn's financial visualization, and your next amazing project. We can't wait to see what you ship!

If you run into any bugs or have any feedback, please let us know at bank@hackclub.com!

You can change your organization's URL by clicking "Settings" in the sidebar. Happy hacking!

Starting today, Hack Club Bank will be sending out seasonal newsletters to share about new features, transparent orgs, and other awesome announcements. ğŸ‰ Feel free toreach out to meif you didn't receive the summer edition and would like to be added!

The financial system in the US isa little slow. In personal finance, that's annoying. For a hackathon organizer who needs tobuy50+burritoswhile herding ~~cats~~ attendees & dodging taxis in NYC, slow money transfers is too much.
As of todaywe've improved our account transfers beta to instantly add to your balance.
Donations usually take 3-5 days from a donor swiping their card to finally arriving in your account. Hackathon organizers often zero out their balance while waiting for a donation payment to arrive.
You can nowrequest afrontfor paid funds that are still in transitâ€“ if your event is happening within 7 days we'll lend you the funds viaan  instant transfer from us, to you. Once the event is over we'll transfer the funds back out of your account.
Eligible invoices and donations have a button to request a front:

Keep in mind we can only front funds that we can confirm paid (ie. they swiped their card successfully, but the funds haven't arrived yet), and we may take up to 24 hours to get your request. Although we're focusing on hackathons running within 7 days, we know everyone has a different story. If you have a special circumstance, please reach outâ€“ we are happy to talk through it with you.
p.s. Users who enabled theaccount transfer betawill also find their transfers reflect in their budgets immediately, instead of the 3-4 days that it used to take.
Little update to the donation form: donors can now contribute to your project using Apple Pay! This feature is now available to all organizations running on Hack Club Bank.

Today we're shipping 3 major improvements to the receipt uploading experience on Hack Club Bank!
Your receipts pageis now smarterâ€“ just click "Add a receipt" or drag & drop a file to instantly attach your receipt. We've also fixed a bug that caused declined & refunded transactions to show up, even though they don't need receipts.The transaction details page has drag & drop, tooâ€“ just drop a file anywhere to upload a receipt to that transaction.
In a busy checkout line? The â€œupload a receiptâ€ link we email you has been totally redesigned for mobile, with the ability to take photos of your receipt directly from the page. If youâ€™re uploading from a tablet or laptop, drag-and-drop is also supported.
Finally, you donâ€™t even have to open Bankâ€“ now you can reply to the â€œupload a receiptâ€ emails with a photo or PDF of your receipt. This is especially useful if you have limited bandwidth and can't load the site.
What's nextâ€“ receipt upload via direct brain connection? We'd love to hear your ideas, both for receipts and other featuresâ€“ be sure to leave us your feedback in Slack or via the Bank interface!

â€“ Caleb and Max
A feature preview is live for users to try out:transfers between HCB accounts.
People who are on multiple teams (ie. running a hackathon and running a club with separate accounts) can manage their money across accounts on Hack Club Bank.

Previously users would have to invoice themselves to move funds. Besides the 7% fee on those funds, it would take between 5-7 days for funds to show up.Transfers cut the time in half and changes "fee" to "free".
You can enable the betain your account settings. Please send me your feedback!
A new feature preview is available for users to opt-into. Once enabled, you can reply to the automated "upload your receipt" emails with your receipt directlyâ€“ no need to click any links.

You can enable the previewin your account settings. Please send me your feedback!

1Password is providing $100 USD of credit to all organizations on Hack Club Bank. If you're not familiar, 1Password is a password manager that allows you to securely keep and share account logins and credentials with your teammates without the hassle; Hack Club HQ uses 1Password too!
To claim the promotion, head to the promotions page on your dashboard and click the â€œApplyâ€ button. Donâ€™t hesitate to reach out via email to bank@hackclub.com or in the#bankchannel on Slack if you have any questions or feedback.
We've just rolled out a set of changes around card charges to give a better understanding of where a transaction came from.

Each of these charges are onHack Club HQ.
Hey everyone! (ğŸºğŸº noises) Iâ€™m announcing my first ever feature contribution to Hack Club Bank. ğŸ‰ On your homepage, after logging in, you can now use the section called"Feedback"to ... well I think you can guess ... submit any ideas you have for cool new features on Bank! As always, you can still continue to reach out to us on theHack Club Slackor byemail.

Few things are as essential to the banking experience as photo IDs. You always gotta wait for the teller to get a real good look at you, and your ID, before making a transaction. (after all, you wouldn't want your near-identical evil twin stealing your hard-earned money)
The Hack Club Bank experience should feel as good or better than a physical IRL bank. Now,you can sign in using just your face (or fingerprint), on supported devices & browsers.

Currently, this includes modern versions ofGoogle Chrome,Safari, andEdge(as well assomeversionsof Firefox), but you can check for support on your current deviceusing this nifty website.
Have a Yubikey? Guess what: Bank supports hardware security keys too!
To get set up, head on down to the brand newSecurity Keyssection of your Bank settings. You'll be enjoying faster sign-ins in no time!
I hate passwords. I can neverremember them when I need them, each new account I create means another'unique' password, andpeople are great at leaking them. Wereallydon't want to burden everyone with all that just to access their financial platform, so now it's even easier to login to Hack Club Bank without a password.
I'm happy to announce thatyou can now get login codes for Hack Club Bank via SMS.The feature can be enabled fromyour settings page.

Users on iPhone and some Android phones can autofill their SMS login code.
You can now get your passwordless login code that much fasterâ€“ reducing login on some devices down to under 10 seconds.
This post is to explain the background details of our switch to Stripe Issuing. Accounts that need action to make the switch will receive an email.
Emburse cards have been a feature since one of the earliest versions of Hack Club Bank, allowing any team member to spend money with a debit card without dealing with reimbursements. While thatâ€™s been amazing, there have been a few trade-offs with using Emburse:
These trade-offs made sense when we first started, but lots of details have changed in the last 2 years. Hack Club Bank has grown byâ€¦I started doing the math on this, but the comparison is stupidâ€“our first year on Emburse has less than $1k spent per month, last week Bank users spent $20k through their cards. Emburse has been acquired (by a company that renamed to Emburse) & have shifted their product features.
Recently Emburse announced theyâ€™d be removing the card budgeting feature Bank currently relies on. If we stayed on Emburse the new flow would require organizers to request funds for a purchase, staff (Michael / Chaleb) to approve the purchase amount, then the card could make the transaction. Emburse was super gracious about the change, delaying the budget feature removal long enough for us to switch to another platform.
The card alternative weâ€™ve eyed for awhile is Stripe Issuing, but it was in private beta we couldnâ€™t access when we built Hack Club Bank. At the time of writing, weâ€™ve got a private version of Stripe Issuing cards running on Hack Club Bank (only available to admins) to make sure our new system works. Iâ€™m happy to say it improves many of the previous issues with cards:
This is obviously a big change, and if you have any questions/comments please let us know either by reaching out to bank@hackclub.com or posting in the#bankchannel on Slack.
4 major improvements to Bank live today:
All of this is live for everyone now. More to come! ğŸ‘€
Thanks to our generous friends over at repl.it, in light of COVID-19,Hack Club Bank users get a free Hacker plan for the next year. Repl.it is an amazing web IDE, where you can get basically any programming language running in your web browser in just a few secondsâ€”regardless of what kind of computer you have. The Hacker plan, normally $84, gives you private projects, unlimited collaborators, & unlimited storage. Theyâ€™ve generously sponsored many events that have run on Hack Club Bank, and weâ€™re so thankful for their continued support.
To claim your subscription, visit the promo page & click "Apply". Itâ€™s limited to the first 500 people who claim it, so donâ€™t wait.
Hope youâ€™re safe & well. If you have any questions, donâ€™t hesitate to reply & ask away!
Last week, we launched a new feature in Hack Club Bank:Transparency Mode.
With Transparency Mode, you can open source your finances instantly from your account settings page. Why would you want to do that? Nonprofit donors deserve to know what their contributions are fundingâ€”as a hackathon/nonprofit, you can talk about what youâ€™re spending money on, but transparency in every transaction builds trust for supporters. Itâ€™s already live in action!
Thatâ€™s not all. When Hack Club first started, Zachâ€™s hope was to build a different kind of organization: one not only open source with code, but open source with its finances too. Every month, Zach would painstaking put every transactionon GitHub. Unfortunately, as we grew, the tooling took too long & we had to outsource our books to an accounting firm that didnâ€™t know what GitHub was.
Weâ€™ll be sharing this publicly next week, but Bank users are getting a sneak peek today:Hack Club HQ has been running entirely on Bank for months now, and our finances are public. Dig in, right here:bank.hackclub.com/hq.
Letâ€™s set a new standard in financial transparency for nonprofits. If you have any questions or feedback on how to improve Transparency Mode, please let us (bank@hackclub.com) know!
Today, weâ€™re announcing withMajor League Hackingthat Hack Club Bank is the new preferred financial platform for allMLH Member Events.
With this announcement,Cal Hacks, the worldâ€™s largest college hackathon, is announcing their switch to Hack Club Bank.Spectrais joining them as well.
Click here to read Linus's full post on this announcement.
Bank can now predict the future! ğŸŒ€ğŸ‰
If you want to know when your invoices are coming in, or how much money is going to be automatically withdrawn from your account, Bank will now tell you.
Check it out by clicking on either "Incoming Deposits" or "Pending Withdrawals" on your Bank dashboard.
If you've ever wanted to get that old, unpaid invoice off of your invoices page, you now can.
Check it out by clicking "Archive" when you're viewing an invoice. ğŸš¢ğŸ‰
You can now upload custom  profile pictures on Bank.
Check it out by navigating to the Team page and then selecting the settings icon next to your user. ğŸ‰ğŸ‘Œ
Have you been stuck with a lame URL likehttps://bank.hackclub.com/hack-pennsylvaniaand have wanted to change it to something likehttps://bank.hackclub.com/hackpenn?
Well, now you can!
Check it out in the your Bank's settings. âœ¨ âš¡ï¸
We've added a document to all projects that you can give to sponsors confirming that you're fiscally sponsored by Hack Club.
Check it out in your Documents tab! âœ¨â˜ï¸
Have you ever wanted to attach an image or link to a transaction or invoice? Well, now with the addition ofMarkdown, you can.
Power up your notes now! ğŸš€
Starting today, there's no longer a fee for accepting credit cards, bank transfers, or any other payment method.
You've invoiced Balsamiq for $500, they paid via credit card, but you only received $485.20. Where'd that $14.80 go? Welcome to the world of payment processing. (HC Bank usesStripe)
Payment processing fees are annoying. Calculating them ahead of time is frustratingÂ and the result is alwayslessmoneyÂ for your event, club, or project.
Starting today, Hack Club Bank will make all your payment processing fees disappear.
This means that regardless of whether a sponsor is paying via credit card, ACH, or wire, when you send an invoiceÂ for $500, you'll receive $500.
And we're taking it even further.
I'm proud to shareÂ we're also reimbursing all previous payment processing fees, from all time, for everyone.
Depending on the size of past invoices, you'll receive somewhere between $4.48Â andÂ $390.50 (actual numbers) granted to your HC BankÂ account this week.
If you want to read more, check out ourblog post with the full story.
P.S. We also resigned the invoice page to show you way more details.

title: Hack Club, Dhupguri Science Club

Hack Club, Dhupguri Science Club is the first ever Hack Club of North Bengal. We are a bunch of computer, technology and science
enthusiasts. The Hack Club started it's journey in January 2023.Nisarga Adhikaryis currently leading the club.We try to make the world a better place with the help of technology and also take initiatives to spread the light of technology among students. We also organize hackathons, workshops, quizzes and more! If you're a person who loves tech, you are welcome to join us!
Dhupguri Science Club is a voluntary organization committed to culture, cultivation & cause of science for scientific outlook. Dhupguri Science Club was estabilished in 2017 by Partha Ghosh. Dhupguri Science Club is registered under the Government Of West Bengal: S0009937 (India).
The club currently has over 500+ members. The majority of the members of the club are students.
Members of this club have participated in many prestigious competitions and events like National Science Congress.
Our club organizes educational seminars, competitions, quizzes, excursions & other awesome events.
You can check out the club's Facebook pagehere.

title: Epoch Bay Area
content:
Join us for an epic 12 hours ofbuilding projects,socializing, andfun.
Whether you've never written a line of code, or you've been
                hacking for years, we'd love for you to come!
Epoch BA is a hackathon organized by the attendees. Come
                organize with us in the#epoch-bachannel in theHack Club Slack.
Epoch, byHack Club, is a global event happening in regions (New Delhi,Vermont, Austin) around the world.
Epochis a high school hackathon
        organized by teenagers inHack Club,
        taking place in New Delhi. Running alongside Epoch are regional events
        (Epoch Bay Area is one of them).
Epoch Bay Area will be held at Circuit Launch (located at8000 Edgewater Dr., Ste. 200, Oakland, CA 94621), from 9am to 9pm on December 30th.
All middle and high school students are welcome. You don't need any
        coding experience to attend! If you've graduated high school but would
        still like to help out (by mentoring or running a workshop), send us an
        email atteam@epochba.hackclub.com.
Epoch Bay Area is completely free :D. We'll provide food (breakfast,
        lunch, and dinner), snacks, and swag!
Awesome, can't wait to see you there! You'll receive an email in the
        next couple of weeks with waivers youmustfill out to attend. In
        the meantime, join theHack Club Slackand come chat with other attendees in the#epoch-bachannel!
Email us atteam@epochba.hackclub.com, or ping @epochba-team in the Hack Club Slack.

earn your callsign,get a free radio
Learn about radio communication and earn your technician license, the first step in your ham radio journey.
Join our program for nightly study sessions from 8-9 PM Eastern Time. If you can't make it, you can study at your own pace.
If you pass your test by May 31st, we'll send you a ham radio! (Note: this is for people under Middle/High Schoolers only!)
Upon passing your exam, we'll send you a UV-K6 radio for hands-on experience in the world of ham radio.
Hack Club is a nonprofit helping technical high schoolers around the world. Collaborate, get help, andsupport others as you get on the air.
Want to jump right in? Check out ourlist of ham radio resources and FAQs!
Hack Club is a registered 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that supports a network of 20k+ technical high schoolers. We believe you learn best by building when you're learning and shipping technical projects with your friends, so we've started You Ship, We Ship, a program where you ship a technical project and we ship you something in exchange. In the past few years, wefabricated custom PCBs designed by 265 teenagers,hosted the world's longest hackathon on land, andgave away $75k of hardware.

title: Hacky Holidays ğŸ„
content:
Create your own custom PCB design.
Add artistic elements to your PCB.
Develop the firmware for your PCB.
Want something a little simplier to learn the basics, or just in need of some inspiration?Check out Hack Club Jams which you'll find amazing guides made by the community.
After deciding on the theme or holiday of your PCB, start brainstorming possible features and ideas for it. We'll help you along the way by providing guidance through Slack huddles and with our guide to use as a reference schematic.
The hard deadline is January 20th, but we recommend submitting much earlier to get your PCB before then!
You can still apply for the OnBoard grant, but you cannot receive two grants for the same PCB design.
We allow both KiCad and EasyEDA projects, however we strongly recommend people submit with KiCad. As a bonus, check out theKiCad-Wakatimeplugin to earn doubloons for High Seas.
A limited handful of people will be eligible to have their PCB hand soldered by a Hack Club staff member. You can apply for it on a form. Applyherefor the service.
Submit your design via a pull request (PR) to the OnBoard repository before the deadline.

headings: Design a holiday themed PCB this Winter, and get it shipped

This holiday season make a festive themed PCB design of one of the many holidays taking place, Christmas, New Years, Diwali, Hanukkah, or others! Design a PCB that commemorates and showcases your interest in electronics using LEDs, sensors and more. The PCB can be a decoration, a gift, or anything else you can think of!Your PCB can be as simple or as complex as you want, to help you get started we have some example designs and reference schematics location in ourguide.

We are55,056teen hackersteen hackersfrom around the world who code together
Every day, thousands of HackÂ Clubbers gather online and in-person to make things with code. Whether youâ€™re a beginner programmer or have years of experience, thereâ€™s a place for you at HackÂ Club. Read about ourhacker ethic.
Connect with other teenage codersHave a coding question? Looking for project feedback? Youâ€™ll find hundreds of fabulous people to talk to in our globalSlack(like Discord), active at all hours.
Build open source learning toolsWe build large open source projects together (3k+Â PRs a year) like this website, a game engine, daily streak system, and more!
Gather IRL with other makersMeet other HackÂ Clubbers in your community to build together at one of the 400+HackÂ Clubsandhigh school hackathons.
We gather both online and in-person to share our love of code and make things together!
Build personal projects. Get free stuff.Oct 30 - Jan 31
HACK CLUB'S BEGINNER FRIENDLY GAME JAM100+ CITIES NOV 23-24
Pacific Crest TrailJuly 12-19
30 Hack Clubbers went on a 7 day hike along the Pacific Crest Trail supplied by only the technical equipment that they built.
Coding doesnâ€™t have to be a solitary activity. At HackÂ Club, we make remarkable things together, and in our Slack youâ€™ll find awesome people to hang out with too. Code together, find your programming community, dream up something wild, or just #lounge.
Occasionally we invite someone we really want to speak to (like Sal Khan, George Hotz, and Lady Ada) and host anAMAwith them.
In collaboration with engineers on the HackÂ Club team, Hack Clubbers build learning tools for each other. Get involved with these projects by building something with our tools or contribute to the tools themselves.

0projects built

Play your own Sprig games on this console, which you can assemble and disassemble. Each kit includes parts needed for getting started with hardware engineering and embedded systems programming.
100+ community-contributed, self-guided coding tutorials and ideas. Learn to code by building, one project at a time.
Thousands of Hack Clubbers organize and participate in hackathons and after school coding clubs.
Join or start a HackÂ Club and be part of a network of high quality coding clubs where you learn to code entirely through building things.
You can start with no experience and build and ship a project every meeting.
We support the largest network of high school hackathons in the world. From an online community of organizers to free stickers and more!

title: HCB Blog
content:
We're working on making detailed transaction information available to you all; incoming ACH transfers now include details about who sent the ACH:
And, if an international wire is returned, we're now surfacing the return reason.
Hope this helps you all navigate the complex financial world!
Ever had a sponsor pay an invoice by check? It's awkward because then you're stuck with an "unpaid" invoice on HCB.
You can now mark invoices as paid if a sponsor pays using alternative means (check, cash, etc.):
We're experimenting with something new - drop in an invoice to the ACH or check form and HCB will do itâ€™s best to autofill any fields.
Try it out and let us know what you think.
HCB's donation page is a great way to raise money for your organization. With one click, you can share a link to your donation page on social media, in emails, or on your website. It's incredibly versatile, but how do you know which platforms perform best?
Starting today, you can analyze which website referred your donors, and, for more granular insights, theUTM parametersof the link they clicked. This data is available on the transaction details page for all donations with referrer data.
Hopefully this feature will help you understand where your donors are coming from and how to better reach them in the future!
Right now, HCB's login page is a little boring. It gets the job done, but it's by no means exciting. That's why we're thrilled to unveil our refreshed login experience!
It features a sleek, intuitive design and now includes a gallery of handpicked images from iconic organizations running on HCB. Plus, it provides some insight into what HCB is all about.
We're hoping the new design improves your experience on HCB and we're always happy to hear feedback.

For as long as I can remember, HCB has been usingÂ HeadwayÂ to announce product updates and changes to users, but over time our needs have shifted. Along with changelog updates, we want to share more content online, like engineering deep-dives, our monthly newsletters, and more.

Exciting news for organizations doing work outside the US! HCB now supports sending money to overseas bank accounts via an international wire:
To send an international wire, you'll need your recipient's bank's SWIFT code and account number as well as some country-specific information. Once you've got that, it's just like sending an ACH transfer to a US bank account on HCB.
Unfortunately, wires are expensive to send. Our partner bank charges us $25 per wire; therefore, to keep HCB sustainable without passing this fee onto you, each wire sent must be at least $500. We've waived this requirement for organizations that have raised over $50k.
If you have any feedback on this wires feature, we'd love to hear from you! We're always looking to improve our product, and wires has been a difficult feature to polish.
When we need help from you, we want to make sure we're reaching out to the right people.
By default, we'll email everyone who is a part of your team on HCB. However, if you have a shared team email or would prefer for us to reach out to a specific email, you can now let us know.

Transparency Mode has been one of HCB's flagship features for years. It revolutionized nonprofit financial transparency and allowed donors and the public to see how an organization utilizes funds. However, we've found that showcasing every transaction can sometimes mean extra housekeeping work for teams to keep the ledger tidy.
That's why we're excited to announce AI-powered memos for transactions!
Now, with 1-click, you can generate a transaction memo summarizing the receipt for any transaction. It's pretty simple:
Upload a receipt to a transaction.
Click the purple AI button to generate a memo.
Accept the suggestions by clicking the checkmark or pressingÂ [enter].

You'll also notice that the receipt sidebar now includes some extracted information that provides a glanceable overview of the receipt's contents.
As usual, we want to hear what you think!

Hack Club HQ is running four events in the next few months to empower girls and nonbinary students who code! All these events are running on HCB, using Transparency Mode. Each hackathon kicks off with a dinner featuring trailblazing women in tech.To learn more about these events and how to get involved, click here.
Golden hackathon, Bay Area, Sept 28th: workshops on Data Science, 3D Printing, and Web Development, with participants from Mission YoungArts, Home Away from Homelessness, and local schools.
Luna hackathon, New York City's Civic Hall, October 5th, with Girls Who Code on Web Development, Project Pitching, and Video Game Development with Sprig.
Celestial hackathon, Toronto, on October 19th at Shopify, will feature sessions on building PCBs, 3D modeling, and AI.
Ascend summit, Los Angeles, in mid-November, bringing together 50 girls and non-binary Hack Club leaders from around the world to code and meet mentors.

In the dark days of HCB, inviting people to your organization was always a binary risk assessment - "do I give this person unfettered access to everything, or nothing at all?"
Once we realized this was Suboptimal And A Bit Dangerousâ„¢ï¸, we started to think about operational security from users' perspectives more carefully.
User roleswas step one. This introduced predetermined permission sets to control users' access in an organization.
Today,we're introducing spending controls. This allows managers of HCB organizations to impose a finer level of control on how much money a member can spend.
To get to a team member's spending controls page, visit the Team page and click on the$icon next to their name.
A team member's spending controls page gives you consolidated details of how they're using their cards.
When controls are disabled, a member can spend any amount of money with their cards. (Since they're not managers, so still can't transfer via ACH, check, HCB transfer, etc.)
With spending controls enabled, new transactions on Fiona's card will be approved/declined based on Fiona's balance. Since we haven't given her an allowance yet, her balance is zero! (as seen above)
Hint: click theNewbutton on the top right.
Now that I've given Fiona an allowance, she can spend it with her card! This $2,500 didn't leave the organization's balance when I created an allowance. Instead, both balances will decrease when she makes a purchase.
You should probably also know that these allowances are not time-dependent. They don't expire, and they do not recur (it's not a weekly/monthly limit).
As a convenience, you can also choose to enable spending controls and set an initial amount when you invite someone to your organization.

As your organization grows, so too does the number of people you invite to HCB. Today, we're handing you the keys to lock down critical actions to your most trusted team members.
When managing your team on HCB, you now have the choice of assigning users one of two roles:managerormember.
Managerscan do everything, just like everyone could before. This includes actions like editing your organization's settings, managing other users, and sending money (ACH, Check, HCB transfer, etc.).
Membershave limited permissions, but they can still spend money using their HCB card.

The holidays are coming up and we know many of you are trying to keep yourselves off the accountantsâ€™ naughty list. And that means uploading receipts! To aid you in your recordkeeping endeavors, weâ€™re launching a brand new feature: Receipt Bin.
Receipt Bin allows you to upload your receipts now and worry about them later. Rather than scrambling to upload the receipt to the right transaction, you can just text it or email it to us. Weâ€™ll hang onto them for you and will try to suggest which transaction they belong to. You can then swing by the new-and-improved Receipt Center at any time to link the receipts from your Receipt Bin to their corresponding transaction.
Text(864) 548-HACKor head tothe settings pageâ€¬to get started today!
Starting today, in addition to a CSV or JSON file, you can now export your transaction into a Ledger file for use with theLedger CLI.
You may be wondering, what's the backstory behind Ledger? Five years ago, Hack Club HQ used Ledger to keep track of and open source all it's finances:https://github.com/hackclub/ledger. It became too much to maintain. When HQ itself began using HCB, we built Transparency Mode so that we could continue open sourcing our finances. That said, Ledger still is awesome. So now, if you'd like to use the Ledger CLI and are on HCB, you can export your transactions to the.ledgerfile format and have fun exploring your money in the terminal!
Additionally, you can also export the transactions of organisations with Transparency Mode enabled, check out HQ's finances:https://hcb.hackclub.com/exports/hq.ledger.
Hey folks! We've got two brand new bits of info to share with you all. First, Hack Club Bank isgrowingâ€” we just hit ğŸ’¸ $10,000,000 ğŸ’¸ in total transactions for fiscally sponsored organizations! Go you! (and this doesn't even include Hack Club's money!)
Second bit of news: the government has some rules about who canâ€” and cannotâ€” call themselves a bank. Now that we've grown a LOT, it's time to change the way we refer to ourselves. As of today,we're shortening our name to HCB.
To celebrate, here are 10 acronyms for HCB:
We can now be found athcb.hackclub.com,hackclub.com/hcb,hcb@hackclub.com, and so on. Not to fret, though; all of your old links will redirect, and we can still be reached at our old email.
We're still the same ol' fiscal sponsor you know and love, just with a few fewer letters.New name, same great taste!
Tired of having transactions declined because you accidentally put in your address instead of ours? Now you can edit your billing address (and update payment information accordingly) wherever you Bank!

Say goodbye to baring the heavy prestige of Fiona Hackworth III, and just be known as Fiona!
While we are required to collect legal names for compliance, most places on Hack Club Bank will now just show your preferred name (if set).
Go to your settings and set your preferred name today!

Hi HCB users! Has it been your lifelong dream to use Google Workspace? â˜ï¸ Have you ever wanted to make your emails even more awesome with the flair of a custom domain? Well, now you can - we're relaunching the Google Workspace perk! ğŸ‰
Head on over to your org on Bank, and you'll find that there's now a Google Workspace tab in the sidebar where you can join the waitlist!


Once you've filled out the form, we'll get back to you within the next 48 hours to let you know if you're approved for one of our open slots.
Unfortunately, we still only have a set limit of slots for access from Google to distribute, but we have systems in place now that will open these up more frequently.
ğŸ’° P.S. Orgs with donor funding will be prioritized for open slots.
Now, when you share links from Hack Club Bank on social media or messaging apps, you'll see a preview image accompanying the link, providing the world with an eye-catching window into your organizationâ€™s finances.

At Hack Club Bank, pushing for financial transparency is one of our primary goals. Social media preview images are a small touch that make your finances more shareable and clickable across the web.
Try it out today by enablingTransparency Mode, and enjoy the refreshed visual appeal of sharing your finances!
HCB prides itself on being at the cutting edge of banking technology. But some parts of the financial system are a little... less cutting-edge.

We want to support those systems too, so now, you candeposit checks directly into your Hack Club Bank accountby just taking a photo! Just snap a picture, wait a day or two, and watch the funds roll into your account.

This feature is available now for everyone. Go write yourself a check and deposit it right now, I dare you!
Have a receipt or two missing? Ignore it every week and now that 1-2 receipts has grown into a much larger number?
For those extra receipts, you can now opt-into a receipt report email onyour feature previews page.
This just in: Hack Club Bank accounts now have account/routing numbers, which means you can receive payouts from platforms like Shopify and Venmo!
Here are some cool things you can do with account numbers:
You can receive money from any platform that asks for an account/routing number. For security, your account number is deposit-only: you can't withdraw money using it.
This is live for everyone right nowâ€” check out the new "Account/routing number" page in your sidebar and start receiving money!

Fundraising for your nonprofit or hackathon is hard, and takes time away from actually using the donated money. What if the funds could raise themselves?
To fix this, I added a monthly subscription option to your organization's donation pageâ€” now when a donor sends a payment, they can opt-in to make their donation monthly. No more manually sending invoices every month.

Here'smy own org'smonthly donation page!
This feature is live for everyone right nowâ€” you don't need to opt-in. You can see your recurring donors in your dashboard's Donations tab:

Hope this helps you spend less time fundraising, and more time doing whatever it is your nonprofit does.
As of today you can test out a new preview feature:SMS notifications when you swipe your card.
Emails aren't always immediate, and when you're dashing through the checkout line at Costco while stocking up on breakfast for your hackathon 2 minutes could be the difference between remembering to take a photo of your receipt or  throwing it away entirely.
Now with SMS notifications, you'll get this:

When you use your card in-person, you'll get a text with a link to upload your receipt. You can opt-in to the feature preview from yourfeature previewspage.
In the future we can add the ability to reply directly to the text with a photo of your receipt.
You can name your card to help keep everything organized (eg. General Spending, Online Retailers, Amazon). Renameyour cardsby clicking on the edit name button when viewing your card.

Your homepage is now a bit more customizableâ€” if you're a member of several organizations on Bank, you can now change their order just by dragging them around!

Hey all! Today hackathon grants are live.
In case you missed it, weâ€™re distributing $500 grants for IRL high school hackathons with the help ofFIRST.
If you're planning to run your own,check it out.
Additionally, weâ€™re waiving the 7% fee for IRL high school hackathons until Dec 31st. That means any funds you raise between now and then are fee-free! You can check your fee status on your eventâ€™s settings page.
P.S. The first grant hasalready gone out!

Renaming transactions is a great way to organize your finances on Hack Club Bank. It also helps team members and supporters to understand how your organization's money is spent. Upon renaming a transaction, you'll now be provided with a dropdown list of suggestions based on similar, previous transactions in your transaction history!

Donations and invoices now deposit in the time it takes for you to read this sentence.
With many financial systems, money can take up to two weeks to move. But now on Hack Club Bank, gone are the days when you had to wait. Behind the scenes, we will seamlessly loan you the incoming funds.
The money will be âœ¨ instantly âœ¨ available for your pizza buying needs!

â€” Gary, Ella, and Caleb
Want to add some pizzazz to your organization's donation page? You can now upload a logo and header image to make your donation page feel a little more like yours.

See it in action athack.af/donate, or try it out yourself by clicking "Donations" in your sidebar!
pssst! developers! you can now see organization logos in theAPI'slogofield!
Hey fellow Bankers!
Every event needs a great venue and with a great venue comes insurance requirements... but where do you start?! A Google search lands you so many options and probably more questions than when you started...

Partnering withThe Event Helper, weâ€™ve created a streamlined process for you to purchase event insurance on Bank without the hassle. You now have access to a simplified, custom form in your â€œPerksâ€ tab, and once submitted, Bank team will provide you with a custom quote. All of the costs are directly from The Event Helper â€“ we don't charge a fee on top!
We're excited to share that Hack Club Bank now has an official public API.
TheHack Club Bank APIis a read-only, unauthenticated REST API which enables you to read public information from organizations withTransparency Modeenabled. This includes transaction history like checks, ACHs, invoices, transfers, donations, as well as organizations and their respective team members.
This API will pave the way for more applications likeSlack Club Bank,HackPenn's financial visualization, and your next amazing project. We can't wait to see what you ship!

If you run into any bugs or have any feedback, please let us know at bank@hackclub.com!
â€” Ella, Caleb, and Gary
Have you ever wanted to change your organization's URL? Previously this was a dangerous affair; bookmarks to the old URL would just stop working, including your donation page.
Now, we'llautomatically redirect your old URL to your new one! It's like magic.
You can change your organization's URL by clicking "Settings" in the sidebar. Happy hacking!

Starting today, Hack Club Bank will be sending out seasonal newsletters to share about new features, transparent orgs, and other awesome announcements. ğŸ‰ Feel free toreach out to meif you didn't receive the summer edition and would like to be added!

The financial system in the US isa little slow. In personal finance, that's annoying. For a hackathon organizer who needs tobuy50+burritoswhile herding ~~cats~~ attendees & dodging taxis in NYC, slow money transfers is too much.
As of todaywe've improved our account transfers beta to instantly add to your balance.
Donations usually take 3-5 days from a donor swiping their card to finally arriving in your account. Hackathon organizers often zero out their balance while waiting for a donation payment to arrive.
You can nowrequest afrontfor paid funds that are still in transitâ€“ if your event is happening within 7 days we'll lend you the funds viaan  instant transfer from us, to you. Once the event is over we'll transfer the funds back out of your account.
Eligible invoices and donations have a button to request a front:

Keep in mind we can only front funds that we can confirm paid (ie. they swiped their card successfully, but the funds haven't arrived yet), and we may take up to 24 hours to get your request. Although we're focusing on hackathons running within 7 days, we know everyone has a different story. If you have a special circumstance, please reach outâ€“ we are happy to talk through it with you.
p.s. Users who enabled theaccount transfer betawill also find their transfers reflect in their budgets immediately, instead of the 3-4 days that it used to take.
Little update to the donation form: donors can now contribute to your project using Apple Pay! This feature is now available to all organizations running on Hack Club Bank.

Today we're shipping 3 major improvements to the receipt uploading experience on Hack Club Bank!
Your receipts pageis now smarterâ€“ just click "Add a receipt" or drag & drop a file to instantly attach your receipt. We've also fixed a bug that caused declined & refunded transactions to show up, even though they don't need receipts.The transaction details page has drag & drop, tooâ€“ just drop a file anywhere to upload a receipt to that transaction.
In a busy checkout line? The â€œupload a receiptâ€ link we email you has been totally redesigned for mobile, with the ability to take photos of your receipt directly from the page. If youâ€™re uploading from a tablet or laptop, drag-and-drop is also supported.
Finally, you donâ€™t even have to open Bankâ€“ now you can reply to the â€œupload a receiptâ€ emails with a photo or PDF of your receipt. This is especially useful if you have limited bandwidth and can't load the site.
What's nextâ€“ receipt upload via direct brain connection? We'd love to hear your ideas, both for receipts and other featuresâ€“ be sure to leave us your feedback in Slack or via the Bank interface!

â€“ Caleb and Max
A feature preview is live for users to try out:transfers between HCB accounts.
People who are on multiple teams (ie. running a hackathon and running a club with separate accounts) can manage their money across accounts on Hack Club Bank.

Previously users would have to invoice themselves to move funds. Besides the 7% fee on those funds, it would take between 5-7 days for funds to show up.Transfers cut the time in half and changes "fee" to "free".
You can enable the betain your account settings. Please send me your feedback!
A new feature preview is available for users to opt-into. Once enabled, you can reply to the automated "upload your receipt" emails with your receipt directlyâ€“ no need to click any links.

You can enable the previewin your account settings. Please send me your feedback!

1Password is providing $100 USD of credit to all organizations on Hack Club Bank. If you're not familiar, 1Password is a password manager that allows you to securely keep and share account logins and credentials with your teammates without the hassle; Hack Club HQ uses 1Password too!
To claim the promotion, head to the promotions page on your dashboard and click the â€œApplyâ€ button. Donâ€™t hesitate to reach out via email to bank@hackclub.com or in the#bankchannel on Slack if you have any questions or feedback.
We've just rolled out a set of changes around card charges to give a better understanding of where a transaction came from.

Each of these charges are onHack Club HQ.
Hey everyone! (ğŸºğŸº noises) Iâ€™m announcing my first ever feature contribution to Hack Club Bank. ğŸ‰ On your homepage, after logging in, you can now use the section called"Feedback"to ... well I think you can guess ... submit any ideas you have for cool new features on Bank! As always, you can still continue to reach out to us on theHack Club Slackor byemail.

Few things are as essential to the banking experience as photo IDs. You always gotta wait for the teller to get a real good look at you, and your ID, before making a transaction. (after all, you wouldn't want your near-identical evil twin stealing your hard-earned money)
The Hack Club Bank experience should feel as good or better than a physical IRL bank. Now,you can sign in using just your face (or fingerprint), on supported devices & browsers.

Currently, this includes modern versions ofGoogle Chrome,Safari, andEdge(as well assomeversionsof Firefox), but you can check for support on your current deviceusing this nifty website.
Have a Yubikey? Guess what: Bank supports hardware security keys too!
To get set up, head on down to the brand newSecurity Keyssection of your Bank settings. You'll be enjoying faster sign-ins in no time!
I hate passwords. I can neverremember them when I need them, each new account I create means another'unique' password, andpeople are great at leaking them. Wereallydon't want to burden everyone with all that just to access their financial platform, so now it's even easier to login to Hack Club Bank without a password.
I'm happy to announce thatyou can now get login codes for Hack Club Bank via SMS.The feature can be enabled fromyour settings page.

Users on iPhone and some Android phones can autofill their SMS login code.
You can now get your passwordless login code that much fasterâ€“ reducing login on some devices down to under 10 seconds.
This post is to explain the background details of our switch to Stripe Issuing. Accounts that need action to make the switch will receive an email.
Emburse cards have been a feature since one of the earliest versions of Hack Club Bank, allowing any team member to spend money with a debit card without dealing with reimbursements. While thatâ€™s been amazing, there have been a few trade-offs with using Emburse:
These trade-offs made sense when we first started, but lots of details have changed in the last 2 years. Hack Club Bank has grown byâ€¦I started doing the math on this, but the comparison is stupidâ€“our first year on Emburse has less than $1k spent per month, last week Bank users spent $20k through their cards. Emburse has been acquired (by a company that renamed to Emburse) & have shifted their product features.
Recently Emburse announced theyâ€™d be removing the card budgeting feature Bank currently relies on. If we stayed on Emburse the new flow would require organizers to request funds for a purchase, staff (Michael / Chaleb) to approve the purchase amount, then the card could make the transaction. Emburse was super gracious about the change, delaying the budget feature removal long enough for us to switch to another platform.
The card alternative weâ€™ve eyed for awhile is Stripe Issuing, but it was in private beta we couldnâ€™t access when we built Hack Club Bank. At the time of writing, weâ€™ve got a private version of Stripe Issuing cards running on Hack Club Bank (only available to admins) to make sure our new system works. Iâ€™m happy to say it improves many of the previous issues with cards:
This is obviously a big change, and if you have any questions/comments please let us know either by reaching out to bank@hackclub.com or posting in the#bankchannel on Slack.
4 major improvements to Bank live today:
All of this is live for everyone now. More to come! ğŸ‘€
Thanks to our generous friends over at repl.it, in light of COVID-19,Hack Club Bank users get a free Hacker plan for the next year. Repl.it is an amazing web IDE, where you can get basically any programming language running in your web browser in just a few secondsâ€”regardless of what kind of computer you have. The Hacker plan, normally $84, gives you private projects, unlimited collaborators, & unlimited storage. Theyâ€™ve generously sponsored many events that have run on Hack Club Bank, and weâ€™re so thankful for their continued support.
To claim your subscription, visit the promo page & click "Apply". Itâ€™s limited to the first 500 people who claim it, so donâ€™t wait.
Hope youâ€™re safe & well. If you have any questions, donâ€™t hesitate to reply & ask away!
Last week, we launched a new feature in Hack Club Bank:Transparency Mode.
With Transparency Mode, you can open source your finances instantly from your account settings page. Why would you want to do that? Nonprofit donors deserve to know what their contributions are fundingâ€”as a hackathon/nonprofit, you can talk about what youâ€™re spending money on, but transparency in every transaction builds trust for supporters. Itâ€™s already live in action!
Thatâ€™s not all. When Hack Club first started, Zachâ€™s hope was to build a different kind of organization: one not only open source with code, but open source with its finances too. Every month, Zach would painstaking put every transactionon GitHub. Unfortunately, as we grew, the tooling took too long & we had to outsource our books to an accounting firm that didnâ€™t know what GitHub was.
Weâ€™ll be sharing this publicly next week, but Bank users are getting a sneak peek today:Hack Club HQ has been running entirely on Bank for months now, and our finances are public. Dig in, right here:bank.hackclub.com/hq.
Letâ€™s set a new standard in financial transparency for nonprofits. If you have any questions or feedback on how to improve Transparency Mode, please let us (bank@hackclub.com) know!
Today, weâ€™re announcing withMajor League Hackingthat Hack Club Bank is the new preferred financial platform for allMLH Member Events.
With this announcement,Cal Hacks, the worldâ€™s largest college hackathon, is announcing their switch to Hack Club Bank.Spectrais joining them as well.
Click here to read Linus's full post on this announcement.
Bank can now predict the future! ğŸŒ€ğŸ‰
If you want to know when your invoices are coming in, or how much money is going to be automatically withdrawn from your account, Bank will now tell you.
Check it out by clicking on either "Incoming Deposits" or "Pending Withdrawals" on your Bank dashboard.
If you've ever wanted to get that old, unpaid invoice off of your invoices page, you now can.
Check it out by clicking "Archive" when you're viewing an invoice. ğŸš¢ğŸ‰
You can now upload custom  profile pictures on Bank.
Check it out by navigating to the Team page and then selecting the settings icon next to your user. ğŸ‰ğŸ‘Œ
Have you been stuck with a lame URL likehttps://bank.hackclub.com/hack-pennsylvaniaand have wanted to change it to something likehttps://bank.hackclub.com/hackpenn?
Well, now you can!
Check it out in the your Bank's settings. âœ¨ âš¡ï¸
We've added a document to all projects that you can give to sponsors confirming that you're fiscally sponsored by Hack Club.
Check it out in your Documents tab! âœ¨â˜ï¸
Have you ever wanted to attach an image or link to a transaction or invoice? Well, now with the addition ofMarkdown, you can.
Power up your notes now! ğŸš€
Starting today, there's no longer a fee for accepting credit cards, bank transfers, or any other payment method.
You've invoiced Balsamiq for $500, they paid via credit card, but you only received $485.20. Where'd that $14.80 go? Welcome to the world of payment processing. (HC Bank usesStripe)
Payment processing fees are annoying. Calculating them ahead of time is frustratingÂ and the result is alwayslessmoneyÂ for your event, club, or project.
Starting today, Hack Club Bank will make all your payment processing fees disappear.
This means that regardless of whether a sponsor is paying via credit card, ACH, or wire, when you send an invoiceÂ for $500, you'll receive $500.
And we're taking it even further.
I'm proud to shareÂ we're also reimbursing all previous payment processing fees, from all time, for everyone.
Depending on the size of past invoices, you'll receive somewhere between $4.48Â andÂ $390.50 (actual numbers) granted to your HC BankÂ account this week.
If you want to read more, check out ourblog post with the full story.
P.S. We also resigned the invoice page to show you way more details.

title: A Home for High School Hackers â€“ Hack Club

We are55,056teen hackersteen hackersfrom around the world who code together

title: Hack Club
content:
Simply put, the purpose of LASA Hack Club is to help 
                            students of all levels of experience reach their full potential through 
                            learning and hacking.
A hacker is often assumed as someone who tries to get unauthorized access to break into a system, but this isn't always true!
The term hacking in this case refers to the action of simply using one's technical knowledge to achieve a certain goal.
Hackathons provide both fun and learning opportunities to all students â€” this club aims to enable students to fulfill 
                    their previously unexplored potential to create through learning and hacking. Students of all levels of experience are welcome! 
                    Through this club, anyone will be able to learn how to derive innovative solutions to current daily problems the world faces.
Simply fill out the form below and text @lasaha to 81010!
Below is a calendar of upcoming events relevant to Hack Club, including upcoming hackathons and meeting descriptions.

title: Hack Club Multiverse â€“ Calling all club leaders!
content:
Calling all club leadersâ€”we need your help to save the multiverse!
REGISTER
We need your help, superleaders. Here are the steps to proceed with your mission.
1
Register Here!
2
Add your project tothis repo
*(don't worry, we have instructions to help you!)
3
Work on and pitch a YSWS/workshop idea!
Itâ€™s completely free to attend! Weâ€™ll have tasty meals, snacks and drinks. We also have travel stipends to cover flights for leaders who live far away from San Francisco. Make sure to complete the 8-week course to be eligible for a stipend!
Any Hack Club leader is welcome to participate! Not a Hack Club leader yet? Apply at hackclub.com/clubs today!
You should bring laptops, chargers, toiletries, sleeping bags, a water bottle and your hacker spirit! A packing list will be provided closer to the event.
Multiverse is an 8-week course on how to build and prototype a collaborative and technical full club YSWS, Club project, or workshop. Once prototyped and run  at a meeting, SuperLeaders will be eligible for travel stipends to come to San Francisco for a 3-day gathering & hackathon where you can work together to get feedback and build your final resource to publish it to the entire clubs community!
The in person event will be held in San Francisco and more details will be released as we get closer to the event!
Yes there are! On the night of the event, we will have gender separated rooms and a supervised sleeping area with dimmed lights and minimal sound for a good sleep. Make sure to bring a sleeping bag & pillow!
Feel free to reach out on #multiverse in the Hack Club Slack or email the team at multiverse@hackclub.com!

title: Riceathon
content:
A Hack Club YSWS where you can rice your Linux desktop and submit your dotfiles to get free programmer socks
Run aLinux Distroon your Computer or Laptop, spend some time spicing it up with customizations and recieve some cool swag to match your desktop.
The term â€˜riceâ€™ is used to describe a personâ€™s unix desktop where â€˜ricingâ€™ is when someone is customizing their desktop such as the icons, panels, or system interface. When it comes to ricing a tiling window manager though, the ricing of a userâ€™s system becomes much more involved. Basic things such as the panel bar and application launcher must be configured by the user.
See the basics of ricinghere
After you submit your rice it will be added to thegallery
On January 10th, so get ricing before the fun is over!
Set upHakatimeand start ricing using the editor of your choice! Hakatime will need to be set up with the same email as your Hack Club Slack account in order to count. You will need to push your customization files to a Github repo once you're done. Afterward,submit a PRto the Riceathon repo with an update to the members.json(check the formatting there for a template!)
Development chatter happens in the#riceathonchannel in theHack Club Slack.

title: anne's cottage
content:
about me|skills|projects|contact me ğŸ’Œ
welcome to my cozy corner on the internet ~~~ i'm ahigh school seniorfrom india and am currently finishing up my college applications..â™¿. i'm going to be majoring in computer science/economics on the pre-law track at uni so i can eventually establish a career incybercriminal law.i'm the founder and club leader of agirls-in-tech after school initiativea> that's affiliated with hack club and is hosted at our local makerspace. it welcomes young, financially underprivileged middle-school aged girls and nudges them towards a sucessful career in STEM. there, i (along with other technical mentors) host workshops on hardware and software; encouraging them to explore, follow along, build amazing stuff, learn new skills and get involved in the tech world.i'mcurrently usingfigma, procreate, ibispaint, canva, blender and adobe illustrator for design, javascript (vanilla), python (basic), html/css, micropython and c++ (basic) to code and arduino, easyeda for hardware stuff.i'mcurrently working onkeeping up my #100daysofcode streak while practicing problems through online courses and code challenges. i'm also grinding for high seas to further develop my portfolio with new codeforgood projects that use different technologies.
      i've been trying to get into music production (using ableton) and am currently experimenting with visual synth and different styles to try to figure out what suits me.i'mcurrently learninghow to transition to linux (and am working my way around it); basic game development with unity; printed circuit boards and general firmware. i'm also reading up on data privacy & cyberspace law. i'm attending a cybersecurity bootcamp in fall '24 + spring '25 and preparing for comptia sec+.iwant to learnabout lower level programming languages, embedded systems, machine learning and gameplay mechanics.i love jamming totaylor swift, reading fanfics, watching true crime documentaries, and baking.feel free to ask me for my socials or contact me viaemail,discordorslackand i'll get back to you as soon as possible.
