title: The Hack Foundation
content:
The Hack Foundation (EIN: 81-2908499) was founded in 2016 to serve as the legal entity forHack Club, a nonprofit network of high schoolers creating the coding education they wish they could have.
In 2018, The Hack Foundation expanded to act as a nonprofitfiscal sponsorfor HackÂ Clubs, hackathons, community organizations, and other for-good projects.
Today, hundreds of diverse groups ranging from asmall town newspaper in Vermonttothe largest high-school hackathon in Pennsylvaniaare fiscally sponsored by The Hack Foundation. Partnered organizations receive the benefits of 501(c)(3) nonprofit status, administrative and backoffice support, financial oversight, and transparency tools.
If you would like to learn more about partnering with The Hack Foundation for your organization,please see here.
The Hack Foundation and all its software have been built over the years by teenagers at Hack Club. Today's supporters include Elon Musk, Vitalik Buterin, Google.org, among many others and hundreds of individual supporters.
As it grows, the Hack Foundation is exploring ways in which it can be responsible, as part of this we have recently madeour entire finances 100% transparent.

title: Timeline | CCHS Hack Club â€“ CCHS Hack Club
content:
We'll be building generative art today!
Hey y'all! We're going to be running another HC meeting today in, of course, room 322. I thought it would be nice for us to take a break from Sprig (personally, I'm almost finished with a Sprig game so I'll hopefully get to bring in a console next week or the week after to show you guys) because people are having trouble with it, so I thought we could learn JavaScript by building Tic-Tac-Toe! Hopefully the code we've written in Sprig will make more sense after today. (Let me know if you're building a game with Sprig! I absolutely want to see it. Email me all hours of the day if you need help.)
Other news. PRs for Winter Wonderland closed a few days ago. Did you guys submit anything? Let me know! I'm going to be turning my bike into an electric bike, which I think is super cool!
I have one last question -IS THERE ANYTHING YOU WANT TO DO WITH PROGRAMMING? Let me know and I can totally run a meeting on it (whatever you want... building a game, working with ChatGPT, building a chat app... whatever's fun for you!)
Hey there! Here's what we're going to be doing today:
Signing up for Slack is another very important thing we need to do.Everyone's going to go home and add their Google Account to their Chromebooks, which should then allow you guys to sign up for Slack while we're running a club meeting. Let me know if there are any problems!
Some other news:

Since it's the last meeting of the year, we're having a pizza party! Here's what we're going to be doing today. I've decided to try out slotting everything into times:
I don't think we'll finish the holiday card during the meeting, but I will have it deployed by the end of Monday! Then, you guys can share it with whoever you want to share it with.
Other news:
Hey guys! We'll be running a meeting today in room 322. I'll help some of you guys with the Sprig workshop, and the rest of you guys can keep working on your games!Also, please take a look at the questions I asked in the December 5 post.
In the meantime, what kind of games are you guys working on? Or leave a "IDK" if you don't know yet.
It's another Monday, so we'll be running a meeting in room 322! We've started working on our Sprig games; I'm in the process of writing a cheatsheet that's going to explain the Sokoban game we created line by line so you guys can understand it better.
If you weren't here last week, that's okay! I can go over the steps to finish your games one by one, and then you can start building your games! Some useful resources include:
Last but not least, HC news this week:
And I have a couple of questions:
Hey, we'll be running a meeting today in room 322! We're going to finish our Sprig games, and then we can probably start building our own games next week! Exciting. Other news:
Hack Club is canceled.
We're running a meeting in room 322 again! This time, I'm going to switch things up a bit - we're going to be building games for the Sprig console! Sprig is a gaming console built by members of HC - it's built with the Raspberry Pi Pico (https://www.raspberrypi.com/products/raspberry-pi-pico/) and anybody who builds a game for it can get a console, which you can use to play games on or repurpose and take apart! For more info and to play some games built by other Hack Clubbers, check out this link:https://sprig.hackclub.com/
We're going to learn how to build a basic game for the Sprig together (I don't know anything about it either), and then we'll each build a game (or more) over the next three weeks or so! At least, that's the plan.
Also, I started a playlist here:https://open.spotify.com/playlist/3APoczNOrVwbAVeYRWGhyf. Please tell me what to include! I have been told by people that I have horrible taste in music, so do not trust me to put together a good playlist.
Other news:
Hey, we're going to be running a meeting today! Let's meet in room 322. We'll be working on the same thing - building websites.
What are you guys planning to build for your websites? Just share the link to your Replit below. And if you're not there yet, it's okay! Please let me know if the workshop is too hard for you - I'll be more than happy to help! Plus, if you want to add stuff like fonts, columns, etc. to your website, let me know.
Have no ideas on what kind of website to build? Also let me know, I've got a couple of ideas!
News of the week:
Kept working on our websites! We had to move to room 322 since ISSN wasn't open.
First meeting! We had donuts and started learning HTML and CSS.

headings: What's CCHS Hack Club up to?

Tip:Set a higher level (Quartile/High) if you want to print this outside, where the QR code will take
            damage from the outdoors. Set a lower level if you need the QR code to be small for some reason (Low). Keep
            it normal otherwise (Medium) :).
QR Codes aren't stored/processed/sold to Google, this website is completely static! :yay:

title: Think Like A Programmer
content:
What is Think Like a Programmer?
Think Like a Programmer is a social tech event open to all Girl Scouts. We'll hang out, build projects, and have fun!
What will the event contain?
Weâ€™ll have workshops covering design thinking, which weâ€™ll use to find creative and innovative solutions to community problems.
What if Iâ€™ve never coded before?
That's perfectly okay! Weâ€™ll be focusing less on coding and more on ideation and problem solving.
Will I need a team?
Nope! Youâ€™ll be working by yourself so you can earn your badge.
How much does attendance cost?
Attendance is $60, which includes your badge! Registration can be foundhere. Financial assistance is available.
What should I bring?
You should bring lunch and a laptop. We also have Chromebooks available if you donâ€™t have a laptop.
My parents or I have another question.
No worries! Contactcustomercare@gsema.orgabout any questions you may have.

title: Spark
content:
Spark is a gender-focused hackathon (social coding event) open to all. We welcome all high school programmers, artists, dreamers, creators to join us for 24 hours of building, exploring, and sharing.
At Spark, you'll have the freedom to create anything you want, learn from your peers, and explore the city. Spark is organized entirely by girls in the Hack Club community, and we want you to help!Join usto craft Spark into the experience you want it to be.
A hackathon is a social coding event -- you get 24 hours, mentors and workshops, and lots of free food and swag to build anything you want. Even if you've never written a line of code before, we'd love to have you there!
That's totally fine! We'll have beginner-friendly workshops and mentors to help you out.
You can fill out the registration formhere!
Bring your laptop, charger, toiletries, a sleeping bag, and anything else you'll need for staying overnight.
Spark is completely free! And (with the support ofSentry), we'll be providing all meals, snacks, and swag.
We're exploring offering travel stipends for hackers from outside the Bay Area; there will be a place for you to indicate your interest on the application form.
Spark is being organized in public on theHack Club Slack, and we encourage attendees to make the hackathon experience their own. Join us in the#sparkchannel on Slack to get involved!
Please contact us! You can find us in the#sparkchannel on Slack, or email us atspark@hackclub.com.

I finished my saxophone MIDI controller ğŸ·! It lets you play any software instrument youâ€™d like using saxophone fingerings, allowing you to practice without disturbing others, create music in any DAW, and perform with it. Check it out athttps://github.com/Whackalenso/CircuitSax
@samuel
Just fixed some final bugs to ship the mobile app for Back on Track America, a nonprofit organization dedicated to serving the homeless and those suffering from food insecurity by coordinating student volunteers in several communities. The app allows volunteers to sign up for their location, receive announcements from location leaders, and discuss upcoming events! âš’ï¸ It's built with React Native & NativeWind on the frontend, and using Pocketbase on the backend. It's also now being submitted for#cider, so that it can get published on the app store! An android build on the play store is also coming soon. Check out the code at https://github.com/backontrackus/app and https://github.com/backontrackus/backend
FAQ
Who is eligible?
You need to be a high schooler (or younger).
How much does it cost?
100% free - all the prizes are donated to us or paid for by us!
What types of projects count?
Anything that you've programmed and is open-source!
How many projects can I build?
All the projects! The land's the limit! (But seriously, you could build as many as you want.)
I need help!
Read the bigFAQ. Still stuck? Reach out in#high-seas-helpchannel of the Hack Club Slack and we'll help you out!
Does school work or a job count?
High Seas is about the joy of building for the sake of building. If you're building something for school or work, we can't count it.
Is this legit?
Yup! This summer, we ranArcade, which gave out similar prizes for working on personal projects.
Build. Battle. Booty. Repeat.
A project byHack Club
Hack Club is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit and network of 30k+ technical high schoolers. We believe you learn best by building so we're creating community and providing grants so you can make awesome projects. In the past few years, we'vepartnered with GitHub to run Arcade,hosted the world's longest hackathon on land, andran Canada's largest high school hackathon. This server is currently on6c16dfcommit.

title: Anti-Hack Club: Cybersecurity Community for Students
content:
Introducing the
The Anti-Hack Club is a network of passionate students learning to keep their Minecraft and Roblox accounts safe through learning the basics of cybersecurity.
Every day, thousands of people are learning how to illegally break into Roblox and Minecraft accounts and retrieve your game status that you spent thousands of hours on within minutes. This is not fair.
Everyday, thousands of accounts are at risk. Not only Minecraft and Roblox, your Facebook, Whatsapp, or even Harris Teeter VIC cards are being illegally accessed.

Learning to cybersecurity is uniquely empowering: you go from a victim to a winner. The goal of Anti-Hack Club is to help you become that winner. We want everyone to be safe when enjoying themselves online.
Take control of your own account security.
Bring the movement to your local community.
The Anti-Hack Club is a network of passionate students learning to keep their Minecraft and Roblox accounts safe through learning the basics of cybersecurity.
Not-Nonprofit at all.
There is no Code of Conduct.
Â©2019Not Hack Club

title: HCB changelog
content:
Which card is which? Is 6014 for this or that? Ugh. If youâ€™re a member of multiple HCB organizations, it can be hard telling your cards apart.
Iâ€™ve started writing the organization name on the back of mine:

Weâ€™ve got a more elegant solution for you all, however. You can now customise the logo printed in the top right and weâ€™ve started printing the organization name on the card:

(Apexis a high-altitude balloon-forcused hackathon running on HCB!)
Plus, weâ€™ve got white cards now. Fancy.

It's that time of year again! We know you've been hard at work on your nonprofit projects, and we want to celebrate the achievements you've made in 2024. That's why we're excited to announce HCB Wrapped 2024, your year in review!

Check it out here:hcb.hackclub.com/wrapped
We hope you enjoy it. Happy holidays! ğŸ‰
Note:You need to have access to the Google Workspace perk on HCB to use this feature
Have you ever needed to have multiple emails for your organization (like help@, sponsor@, [your name]@)?
Previously, you would have had to create a new account for each address, but you no longer need to.
On HCB, you can now create up to 30 aliases per Google Workspace account; all emails to an alias will be sent to its parent account's inbox. No more having to flip through 10 different inboxes!

Today we're launching a new way to stay up-to-date on HCB:our new blog.
For as long as I can remember, HCB has been usingHeadwayto announce product updates and changes to users, but over time our needs have shifted. Along with changelog updates, we want to share more content online, like engineering deep-dives, our monthly newsletters, and more.
With this change, all of our posts are now open source and available onGitHubas well.
We're excited to share more with you in the future. Stay tuned!
For a long time, HCB cards appeared as a mysterious, dark, unbranded card in your Apple Wallet.

Today, we're excited to announce that it's getting a new look! Some people might say it's fresh & crisp, just like a juicy apple ğŸ. Enjoy!

Thanks to Ian and Sam for the design work!
Exciting news for organizations doing work outside the US! HCB now supports sending money to overseas bank accounts via an international wire:

To send an international wire, you'll need your recipient's bank's SWIFT code and account number as well as some country-specific information. Once you've got that, it's just like sending an ACH transfer to a US bank account on HCB.
Unfortunately, wires are expensive to send. Our partner bank charges us $25 per wire; therefore, to keep HCB sustainable without passing this fee onto you, each wire sent must be at least $500. We've waived this requirement for organizations that have raised over $50k.
When we need help from you, we want to make sure we're reaching out to the right people.
By default, we'll email everyone who is a part of your team on HCB. However, if you have a shared team email or would prefer for us to reach out to a specific email, you can now let us know:

Are you trying to manually link your organization'saccount & routing numberswith a 3rd party service? Sometimes these services will ask for a bank account letter that proves you have access to your account number.
Luckily for you, sitting right on your documents page is averification letteryou can share. âœ¨âœ…
This handy one-pager allows organizations on HCB to prove they have access to their account & routing numbers.

Looking for a little bit of extra security? You can now turn on two-factor authentication for your account:

That'll prompt you for two authentication factors each time you log in, whether it's a hardware security key, a login code sent to your email/phone, or a time-based one time password.
You know what they say about 2FA, you may find it mildly annoying but baddies find it infuriating.Ok, no one says that but you get the point.
Are you a part of multiple organizations on HCB? Simply click on your organization's title to navigate between them! ğŸ”¥

title: GitHub - hackclub/assemble: ğŸŒ The behind-the-scenes of the first high school hackathon since the pandemic!
content:
We read every piece of feedback, and take your input very seriously.
To see all available qualifiers, see ourdocumentation.
ğŸŒ The behind-the-scenes of the first high school hackathon since the pandemic!

ğŸ¬ The Mini-Documentary~âœ¨ The Philosophy~ğŸ“† The Event~ğŸ«‚ The Attendees~ğŸ’¸ The Budget~ğŸ“Œ The Venue~ğŸ“š Further Reading
Many Hack Clubbers in 2022 had heard about great IRL hackathons, but very few had been to one. They vanished when the pandemic hit, and went missing as the world emerged from the pandemic. Our 2022 summer project was to kick off a hackathon renaissance, together with Hack Clubbers.
To do this, we hostedthe first major high-school hackathonsince 2020,open sourcedthe entire event &launched a series of supportsfor high school hackathon organisers based on our experience.
The goal of this repository is to be a reference for high schoolers looking to organise their own hackathon. No hackathon is the same but we hope that within this repository you can find inspiration for you own special event.
Looking for a how-to? ReadAn Expandable Guide to Hackathon Organizing.

Ahackathonis not an extracurricular or a club. It's not a class or a lecture. Hackathons are a place to build things for fun and meet others doing the same. Going into organising Assemble,we brainstormed what a magical hackathon looked like, from those brainstorms we developed the following framework for a great hackathon:
Read more about Hack Club's Philosophy âš

Assemble ran from 6PM on Friday to 12PM on Sunday. That's 42 hours to make our own. Creating a great hackathon, means designing a spectacular attendee experience as well as a great organiser experience. There are a fair few components to this including, but not limited to, planned (as well as unplanned)activities,judging,swag,foodandceremonies. The specifics of each at Assemble are detailed in their respective files in/the-event.

Read more in/the-eventâš

There's only so much organisers can do to make a wonderful hackathon, it is the attendees who bring a hackathon alive. As an organiser, your role in this process is to make sureeveryone who needs to hear about your hackathon does, to convert these potential participants into attendees, tomake sure they're all setfor the event and then to inspire them to embrace the spirit of the hackathon. At the same time, you may choose to invite non-high schoolers to mentor and talk with the attendees. At Assemble, we wanted to make sure such relationships were casual and human, an approach you can read more abouthere.
Read more in/the-attendeesâš

Assemble had a budget of $75,000, that's a large budget for a high school hackathon. HS hackathon budgets can range anywhere from $500 to $75,000. Whatever your budget is, you'll find a similar set of expenses will arise between all hackathons. Every expense made for Assemble has been open sourcedherethrough HCB'stransparency mode. As an organiser, you'll need toraise money,create an itemized budget(which accounts for the unexpected) and thenspend the moneyraised as planned.
Explore our budget sheet âšorread more in/the-budgetâš

Since the pandemic began,finding a venuehas became by far the most challenging aspect of organising a hackathon. Assemble was hosted across two floors in Figma's San Francisco office, situated in thePhelan Buildingon Market Street. Getting there took almost 40% of the time spent organising the event, however, when the event rolled around it was well and truly worth it. Figma's space was creatively inspiring and provided the perfect home for Assemble. As an organiser, you'll need to make pitches to potential venues, convince a venue to buy into your event, set up the venue for success and finish by making the venue providerfeel appreciated.
Read more in/the-venueâš
Below you can find a series of resources curated and created by the Assemble team that we hope will help you when organising your own events.
The majority of work on Assemble was done in a month, from July 5th to August 5th. Every week of that month,@sampoderwrote a journal update on the Assemble organising process. Together they tell the story of how Assemble went from an idea to an event for 175 hackers.

Across this repository, you'll find the fabulous photographs of Assemble by@kunalbotla, a Hack Clubber from Boston. The full album can be found here (all Hack Clubbers can use these photos in their projects!):hack.af/assemble-photos. We also have a collaborative album amongst attendees:hack.af/assemble-album.

Just fixed some final bugs to ship the mobile app for Back on Track America, a nonprofit organization dedicated to serving the homeless and those suffering from food insecurity by coordinating student volunteers in several communities. The app allows volunteers to sign up for their location, receive announcements from location leaders, and discuss upcoming events! âš’ï¸ It's built with React Native & NativeWind on the frontend, and using Pocketbase on the backend. It's also now being submitted for#cider, so that it can get published on the app store! An android build on the play store is also coming soon. Check out the code at https://github.com/backontrackus/app and https://github.com/backontrackus/backend
FAQ
Who is eligible?
You need to be a high schooler (or younger).
How much does it cost?
100% free - all the prizes are donated to us or paid for by us!
What types of projects count?
Anything that you've programmed and is open-source!
How many projects can I build?
All the projects! The land's the limit! (But seriously, you could build as many as you want.)
I need help!
Read the bigFAQ. Still stuck? Reach out in#high-seas-helpchannel of the Hack Club Slack and we'll help you out!
Does school work or a job count?
High Seas is about the joy of building for the sake of building. If you're building something for school or work, we can't count it.
Is this legit?
Yup! This summer, we ranArcade, which gave out similar prizes for working on personal projects.
Build. Battle. Booty. Repeat.
A project byHack Club
Hack Club is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit and network of 30k+ technical high schoolers. We believe you learn best by building so we're creating community and providing grants so you can make awesome projects. In the past few years, we'vepartnered with GitHub to run Arcade,hosted the world's longest hackathon on land, andran Canada's largest high school hackathon. This server is currently on6c16dfcommit.

title: Asmgame
content:
Asmgameis a game that teaches you how to write assembly language. The game is based on the concept of a CPU with 3 registers and anaccumulator(which is like another register):A,B, and*A. The game is played by writing assembly language to solve puzzles. The game is designed to be a fun way to learn assembly language. For example, in the first puzzle, you need to write assembly code that swaps the values of theAandBregisters. One way to do this would be putting theAregister in to theaccumulator, putting the B register into the A register(and in doing so overwriting the previous value), and then putting theaccumulatorinto the B register. The game is designed to be a fun way to learn assembly language.

title: Home Page
content:
Alpine is a one-day hackathon, which is an event where participants gather to code projects, learn new things, and have fun! You don't need any coding experience to "hack" with us. At Alpine, we're not actually "hackers," we just love to code and share our projects!This event is organized entirely by high school coders just like you. Alpine is fully open source, and funded and run by the Hack Club community.
We're providing breakfast, lunch, and dinner and lots of cool swag! Register today to join us July 15th!
This event is open to anyone of any gender from 7-12th grade.
Hackers of all skill levels, including beginners, are welcome to join! We will be hosting programming workshops to help you get started!
Alpine is a hackathon, which means you'll be spending the day making your very own project to present at the project showcase. You can make anything, from a website, a game, an app, or whatever you'd like that involves code!
This event is free to all students.
Please bring your own laptop so you can work on your projects! We have a few loaner laptops reserved for those who have limited access to tech. You may also want to bring a water bottle. Breakfast, lunch, and dinner will be provided.
Alpine will be supervised by Bill employees and the organizers in an extremely secure venue.
They can reach out to Abby atabby@hackclub.comand we'll make sure to answer all their questions.

title: Hack Club
content:
Hack Club is a 21st century cultural institution, run by teenagers for teenagers, that prizes technical skills, an entrepreneurial mindset, and a rigorous dedication to building real things in the real world that solve real problems.
Led by young engineers, with early backing from the 21st centuryâ€™s most iconic creators, Hack Club is already in 2 percent of US schools, and represents the largest network of technical teens in the world.
Each day, new projects are shipped, new lines of code are written, and new friendships are forged through collaborative, problem-solving technical projects happening at Hack Club.
With your support, Hack Club can grow from 1,000s to 10,000s of teen hackers, bringing free computer science education, a hacker mindset, and an equal shot at success to every teenager, regardless of where theyâ€™re from, how they identify, or what their parents do.
Fewer than half US highschools offer CS classes
With an annual budget less than a single, small public highschool, Hack Club brings CS education to thousands of teenagers. Our goal: become the Girl and Boy Scouts of the 21st century.
Hack Clubbers at SpaceX, July 2021:See the video
In the next ten years, Hack Club will discover, foster and inspire thousands more teenagers to become highly technical. We help shape the values of these future leaders, modeling and incentivizing them to be curious, humble, kind, optimistic problem solvers.
Hack Club is founded and run by teenagers.
Our board members are all 21st century founders, innovators, and builders.
Most of our team is technical and are building what they wish they had.
Hack Clubbers code in languages like Rust, Typescript, Haskell, Go and ship projects people use.
All teens, regardless of background, join Hack Club.
Hack Club is the only nonprofit in the country with 100% financial transparency
Eleeza, a 16-year-old Hack Clubber from London, UK, created "Double-Edged Blade: All Under Controlâ€, a 2D visual novel video game! She created, illustrated and wrote the entire thing, and along the way she posted updates and asked Hack Clubbers for storyline suggestions all on her personal channel at Hack Club.
"Hack Club is awesomeâ€
â€œThereâ€™s so much positivityâ€
"[Hack Club] has given me the confidence to imagine, build, and explore.â€
Leading a Hack Club at her school
Hosting an AMA with Elon Musk
"Really awesome"
No offense! Aiden, 16, used Tensorflow to trigger a photo every time he gives his device the middle finger. Itâ€™s a parody of selfie culture, and a pretty popular ship at Hack Club!
"After raising $5M for The Fuller Project and taking it from a start-up to an established organization, I knew that this was my chance to help build something poised to make real change in our 21st century world - and, importantly, with girls at the forefront."
"In addition to allowing the public to hold these organizations accountable, transparent finances help founders and board members make the right decisions in the first place since they know theyâ€™re operating under public scrutiny."
"For eight days, the future would roll and click across the USA."
"Teenagers across the country are forming hacking clubs, attending hackathons and trying to spread the word that hacking doesnâ€™t always mean breaking into government servers or stealing bank data."
"Do you know Zach Latta?â€ ... â€œYou know he rebuilt Yoâ€™s backend. Heâ€™sÂ baller.â€
"Zach Latta found many people who were willing to listen, leaving high school to move to San Francisco on his own to start a nonprofit called Hack Club."
Hack Club invites the 21st centuryâ€™s leading thinkers, builders and disrupters to join our small, core network of donors with a gift.
Founded in 2014, Hack Club grew 700 percent during the COVID-19 pandemic, and Hack Clubâ€™s team of engineers canâ€™t keep up with demand.
With your gift, Hack Club could increase engineering support to serve thousands more teenagers, with a strong focus on serving those who face additional barriers to contributing their talents to the world.
â€œHack Club is the organization I wish I had when I was a teenager. In 2017, I joined as a founding board member, and Iâ€™ve seen firsthand the leadership team act with integrity and transparency since Day 1. Founder Zach Latta and COO Christina Asquith are efficient, responsible and disciplined stewards of every dollar, and I've proudly grown my donations over the years.
With major support, I am confident Hack Club will change the world. I have met dozens of teenagers involved in Hack Club, and seen how it already is having an enormous impact in their lives.
Hack Club is inspiring a generation of teenagers to become highly-technical builders, innovators and problem-solvers â€” and it is making the path to success accessible to all young people regardless of background. I believe in Hack Club, and I'm looking forward to staying involved for the long term. I also personally intend to continue and grow my financial support of their mission."

title: Hackerspace Club
content:
Bridging the Gender Gap and Building the Future of Tech
General Interest Forms for the Spring 2025 semester will be out next week and the general interest meeting will be held in January at [redacted] makerspace in South Delhi or online via Zoom.REGISTRATION IS OPEN all year round on a rolling basis and it is completely free! All you need to become a member is:1. Be Female2. Be under the age of 19
Welcome to Hackerspace - Girls in Tech Club! We're an after-school program in New Delhi, India dedicated to introducing young women to the exciting world of technology. We cater towards middle-school / high-school-aged girls in particular and nudge them in the direction of STEM/tech.Accepting young girls at any skill level (be it beginners to advanced), we help girls become a part of the initiative through hands-on projects, mentorship, and collaborative learning. This is done by running coding workshops, building projects together, inviting mentors, asking questions and a whole lot of trial and error.Weâ€™re affiliated with Hack Club and host a lot of events focussed around their programs (like high seas, boba drops, etc.). Weâ€™re always looking for funding and your donations, be it monetary (even the smallest amount helps!) or in-kind (hardware components /  electronics kits/ spare laptops / discounts / gift cards)) would mean a lot to us and help those who we serve. We would love for those in the tech industry to donate your time to sit down for an AMA session and give us an idea of what itâ€™s like working in the IT-sector specifically in India.

title: Hack Club STEM Egypt
content:
Together, we utilize our expertise to build each other up to become better makers and hackers as a whole!
Develop your skills by building quirky, unique projects
Free sessions for everyone to participate and learn something new
Don't worry if you are new to programming; our seminars are highly beginner-friendly, and we are here to assist you at every step along the journey
Event
A hacker is not always someone who trespasses on banks or plunders a friend's V-Bucks. Hackers are individuals who identify problems that need to be solved and devise the most practical-efficient solutions. These issues frequently call for an inventive mentality, technological know-how, and exposure to new ideas. Many can be solved with computers or clever engineering. At STEM Egypt Hack Club, we want our hackers to be creative problem solvers who are also proficient in coding, engineering, and problem-solving.Coding and computer science not only apply to specific problems - it fundamentally teaches how to solve complex problems using step-by-step logic. Coding teaches you how to dissect the issues and find solutions, so knowing it is valuable regardless of the job you end up choosing. STEM Egypt Hack Club cards are mainly focused on coding and engineering, including building unique-new software projects, protecting the community's network, conducting research projects and articles and much more!
We have an official affiliation with the student organizationHack Club, which brings together like-minded makers, coders, and hackers on theSlackplatform. Numerous unique chances are provided by Hack Club, includingAMAswith well-known figures in the tech space, includingElon Musk,Gwen Shotwell,Patrick Collison, andTommy Devoss. Additionally, Hack Club hosts international coding competitions(in-person and online)that are a fantastic opportunity for students to bond and learn what it's like to hack in a
              group setting.

title: Gyat
content:
Insolipsisticdreams I roam,
Where truth and self entwined in foam,
Ontologicalwaves crash with might,
Revealing depths of cosmic light.
In dialectic's dance, we sway,
Through realms of night and shades of day,
Epistemologicalbreeze, so keen,
Whispers secrets yet unseen.
Phenomena, like stars above,
Reflect thenoumena's hidden love,
Metaphysicalechoes, clear and true,
Reveal the essence, old and new.
Axiomatic truths, they guide,
Throughethicalseas, where we abide,
Imperatives command our way,
As we navigate life's grand display.
Though paths may twist and shadows fall,
In the labyrinth, we stand tall,
For in philosophy's grand embrace,
We find our meaning, time and space.

title: BrowserBuddy - Build your own Browser extension
content:
We're limiting to one submission per person.
You must be a teenager or still in high school.
Please reach out in the#browser-buddychannel on Slack.
Your extension should be able to run in both Chrome-based
					browsers like Chrome/Edge/Brave and Firefox.
Googles browser extension tutorialsare a great place to start. Also read aboutbuilding cross-browser extension from MDN.
All you need is a text editor and a web browser. You might
					want to install both a chrome-based browser like
					Chrome/Edge/Brave and Firefox to test your extension.
Hack Club is a registered 501(c)3 nonprofit organization that supports a
    network of 40k+ technical high schoolers. We believe you learn best by
    building when you're learning and shipping technical projects with your
    friends, so we've started You Ship, We Ship, a program where you ship a
    technical project and we ship you something in exchange. In the past few
    years, wefabricated custom PCBs designed by 265 teenagers,hosted the world's longest hackathon on land, andgave away $75k of hardware.

title: Hack Camp â€“ Summer 2019 High School Coding Camp
content:
Hack CampbyHack Club
A 1-week summer campto get started coding.
July 2019 Â· Grades 8â€“12 Â· San Francisco, CA
Applications are now closed!
Computers give us superpowers. Anyone, anywhere, can create beautiful things and solve real problems for people everywhere.
Learning to code is your way into this world. Crossing this bridge unlocks the power to make stories, drawings, or wires into websites, games, robots, and things nobody but you imagine.
Itâ€™s not about learning a programming frameworkâ€”itâ€™s about learning to teach yourself. Best of all, you can join a worldwide community of people doing the same. This is Hacker Culture, & itÂ brings out the best in us all.
Just to be clear: we donâ€™t break in to internet banks. Some hackers specialize in cybersecurity; weâ€™re not especially focused on it.
Every day at Hack Camp youâ€™ll go home with a new finished project. We want some projects to be a surprise, but here are a few youâ€™ll certainly tackle:
A teenager in our community built the website youâ€™re reading from scratch. The first day, itâ€™ll be your turn.
Radios are the basis of Wi-Fi & satellites. Youâ€™ll build one yourselfâ€”but with a pencil, razor blade, & copper wire.
Making a game is a great intro to code, and itâ€™s never been easier. Youâ€™ll go home with your own 3D world.
Morning discussion
What are we doing today?
Morning workshop
Letâ€™s build something awesome together.
Lunch
Afternoon workshop
Progress resumes on incredible stuff.
Project demos
Woah, you built that today??
Camp dismissed
Hack Camp was the single factor that completely shifted my view of CS. I met an unbelievably accepting & kind community of creators & learners that introduced me to an entirely novel approach to hacking, changing not just the way I regard technology, but the way I approach the world at large.
Hack Camp attendee, 2016
Weâ€™reHack Club, a global nonprofit network of high school coding clubs (now in 2% of US high schools). Hack Camp has been a part of Hack Club since the beginning. Itâ€™s a great way for us to try out the best ideas from our community, develop curriculum, and stay sharp as teachers. We also just love doing it!
Fernanda is a student of computational neuroscience, entrepreneur, and organizer with years of experience running events and programs like the Entrepreneurial Learning Academy for students in Mexico. This summer, sheâ€™ll run Hack Campâ€™s logistics and be your primary contact.
Mingjie is a student organizer who has spread his passion for technology to thousands of other students through events like Hack Chicago, CodeDay, and his own Hack Club. This summer heâ€™s working with club leaders around the world to build the ultimate curriculum.
Chris is an all-around hacker enthusiast passionate about building video games, websites, radios, furniture, rockets, fire sculptures, communities, and more! He will be leading Hack Campâ€™s workshops, designing hardware projects, and directing the day-to-day experience.
Hack Camp began as an experiment to discover new ways of teaching coding at our clubs around the world.
After our first year, something incredible happenedâ€”our students began running their own camps! Theyâ€™veÂ sprung up in a suburb of Cincinnati & Southern India.
This was so inspiring to watch that weâ€™re following their lead to bring Hack Camp back in 2019.
2015
Hack Club is born
2015
First Hack Camp in SF
2016
SF Hack Camp v2
2017
A Camp appears in Mason, OH
2018
Camp runs again in Mason
2018
A Camp appears in Kerala, India
2019
Hack Camp returns to HQ!
Hack Camp is a chance for young students to discover their ability to build using code. Your youth is the most defining time of your life, and Hack Camp helped us reach out to students around the community to expose them to the most beautiful, empowering parts of technology.
Camp leader, Harvard â€™23
I was worried campers might lose interest since coding was new to them. But when we got them started, they blew us away. They started learning by themselves during the camp and built things we never taught them.
Camp leader, ASIET â€™21
Weâ€™reÂ running HackÂ Camp right at our office in SanÂ Francisco (576 Natoma St). Hereâ€™s the space.
Weâ€™re running three identical weeks of Hack Camp. Join us July 1â€“5th, 15â€“19th, or July 29thâ€“August 2nd. Camp runs 9amâ€“4pm (weekdays).
July 2019
Need-based financial aid is available for Hack Camp after you apply.
Lunch is! Weâ€™ll serve a healthy lunch & snacks every day at Camp.
Perfect! Youâ€™ll be up to speed in no time. We made this with beginners in mind.
We will cover lots of stuff you donâ€™t know yetâ€”I guarantee it!
A laptop and an open mind. We can help with the laptop. The mind thing is on you.
About 15 students each. Weâ€™re shooting for a 5:1 student-to-instructor ratio.
Sadly we canâ€™t offer official housing, but youâ€™re welcome to find your own & come!
Please reach out! We can be reached anytime atsummer@hackclub.com.
1-855-625-HACK(call toll-free)

Frequently asked questions.
What is a Game Jam?
A Game Jam is an event where programmers, artists, storytellers musicians, and much more come together to create a game in a limited time. We're welcoming beginners and experts alike!
What is hacking? Is it safe?
No, we're not â€œhackingâ€ bank accounts. Hacking is term for coding apps, games, websites etc. It's safe and entirely educational.
What can I make?
Anything related to games! You can make platformers, Sprig games, ARGs, board games. Your imagination is the limit! You can also make assets, music or design levels for games! At the end, we'll vote for each other projects and have prizes for the winners!
Do I need a team?
Nope! You'll have the opportunity to create your own team up to four. We can also put you in a team to meet new people. Find new friends, bring yours, or work alone.
What is Hack Club?
Hack Clubis a nonprofit global network (based in the U.S.) and network of student-led coding clubs & High school makers. Founded in 2014, Hack Clubs are now in nearly 400 high schools with 10,000 students each year.
What is AngelHacks?
AngelHacks started in 2019 has an in-person hacking (programming) event. This year, AngelHacks is Hack Club's offical Spring Event, all organized by high schoolers.
Who can participate in AngelHacks?
AngelHacks primarily targets high school / older middle school students. If you're outside of that range, we're looking for mentors and people to run workshops! If you're intrested, you can fill the form and let us know :)
What if I have never coded before?
At AngelHacks, complete beginners are not only welcome, but expected! Learn as you go with our workshops and mentors. A Game Jam isn't all about code, you can also create art, music, stories and more for games!
What do I need to bring?
You'll need your Student ID, laptop, a phone, chargers and anything else that you might need!
What's the event like? Is it safe?
There will be free food and refreshments. Workshops and activities will be held throughout the event. Adult supervision will be present at all times with access restricted to participants.
I have another question that'as not answered here!
Feel free to email us attoronto@angelhacks.orgor send us a message in #angelhacks-toronto on theHack Club Slack.
AngelHacks Toronto is an event crafted by Hack Clubbers.
Website open sourced athackclub/angelhacks-torontoand finances onHack Club Bank. You can read ourCode of Conducthere!

title: PrintBoard
content:
A Hack Club YSWS where you ship a 3D design that interfaces with the IKEA pegboard, and we will send you one!
The IKEA SKÃ…DIS is a 30 by 22 inch wooden board with many holes for you to connect your designs to the wall. It is often used by 3D modelers and hackers to easily connect prints to the wall without needing screws or adhesives.

Anything you want to store! Some examples are something to store a collectionâ€” like retro games or cards, or something to hold the random electronic parts we all have lying around, or even something to mount a cameraâ€” it can be anything!

title: GitHub - hackclub/epoch: ğŸ† Behind the scenes at Epoch â€” a magical New Year's spent hacking in the Delhi NCR.
content:
We read every piece of feedback, and take your input very seriously.
To see all available qualifiers, see ourdocumentation.
ğŸ† Behind the scenes at Epoch â€” a magical New Year's spent hacking in the Delhi NCR.
On December 30th 2022, 180 hackers from around the world travelled to the Delhi NCR for Epoch â€” a 42-hour high-school hackathon over New Year's. With clubs & hackers in 130+ countries, Hack Club is a truly global community. After many magical summer events in the USA, Epoch was Hack Club's first flagship event outside of the United States. The Hack Club community came together to organise Epoch, the goal of this repository is to document that journey for future organisers to reference.
Epoch was organised in public on theHack Club Slackby dozens of Hack Clubbers. We've kept them open for your exploration. Looking through them will give you insight into the challenges we faced and how we overcome them.
SeeğŸŸ£ Issue #3for additional context surrounding/judging&/theme.
Epoch was made possible by dozens of Hack Clubbers. Thank you. A special thank you to our Temporal Agents:Aaryan,Akshay, Anisha,Arash,Arav,Arsh,Ashish,Christina,Dev,Fayd,Gaurav,Kara, Karan,Mahi,Neil, Nila,Nishant,Ojas,Sam, Shatakshi,Tej,Khaleel&Zach.

Just fixed some final bugs to ship the mobile app for Back on Track America, a nonprofit organization dedicated to serving the homeless and those suffering from food insecurity by coordinating student volunteers in several communities. The app allows volunteers to sign up for their location, receive announcements from location leaders, and discuss upcoming events! âš’ï¸ It's built with React Native & NativeWind on the frontend, and using Pocketbase on the backend. It's also now being submitted for#cider, so that it can get published on the app store! An android build on the play store is also coming soon. Check out the code at https://github.com/backontrackus/app and https://github.com/backontrackus/backend
FAQ
Who is eligible?
You need to be a high schooler (or younger).
How much does it cost?
100% free - all the prizes are donated to us or paid for by us!
What types of projects count?
Anything that you've programmed and is open-source!
How many projects can I build?
All the projects! The land's the limit! (But seriously, you could build as many as you want.)
I need help!
Read the bigFAQ. Still stuck? Reach out in#high-seas-helpchannel of the Hack Club Slack and we'll help you out!
Does school work or a job count?
High Seas is about the joy of building for the sake of building. If you're building something for school or work, we can't count it.
Is this legit?
Yup! This summer, we ranArcade, which gave out similar prizes for working on personal projects.
Build. Battle. Booty. Repeat.
A project byHack Club
Hack Club is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit and network of 30k+ technical high schoolers. We believe you learn best by building so we're creating community and providing grants so you can make awesome projects. In the past few years, we'vepartnered with GitHub to run Arcade,hosted the world's longest hackathon on land, andran Canada's largest high school hackathon. This server is currently on6c16dfcommit.

Since every single power grid has sounds unique to a timestamp, it's possible, in theory, to accurately match any audio sample to an exact time (and general region) of recording. We can even verify the authenticity of any audio sample! However, for this approach to be successful, it needs data to match against â€” I used Nest and some networking shenanigans to collect second-by-second data to create the only current and complete (ish) dataset of the European power grid.

title: Wonderland
content:
Welcome to Wonderland, Hack Clubâ€™s winter hackathon in
                    Boston.
Here, we are surrounded by Wonderlandâ€™s knicks and knacks,
                    the various tools and parts that fell down the rabbit hole.
                    As you survey the land, you see the many projects hackers
                    have made before you, all constructed from the very items
                    that came with you.
Some of you may be used to events where the only prompt is
                    tomake. Some of you may be familiar with
                    building projects that try to â€œwin.â€ Wonderland isnâ€™t like
                    that.
In the heart of Boston, we challenge you and your team to
                    take the rabbit holeâ€™s random assortment of partsâ€”chestsâ€”and
                    turn them into something thatâ€™s truly wonderful.
Only when we limit ourselves do we become truly free.
Boston, MA from the evening of Friday, February 23th to the
                    morning of Sunday, February 25th.
Join us.
The first thing every project needs is a clear,
                    well-thought-out plan. Right???
When we start a project, we often start by figuring out the
                    "right" way to start, or the â€œrightâ€ tools to use. We
                    research Python vs Typescript, ATTiny vs ATMega. More often
                    than not, we lose the very thing we started with: excitement
                    about our idea!
But what if youdonâ€™thave every tool in
                    the world? What if youcanâ€™tuse the right
                    tool for the job? What ifall you haveis
                    the stuff within armâ€™s reach? Only when youâ€™re limited do
                    you find yourself truly free â€” free tojust start making.
IntroducingChestsâ€” Wonderland's mystery
                    boxes of knicks and knacks. From aPython horoscope libraryto a rubber duck, your job will be to find a way to make a
                    project with them.
Weâ€™re super excited to announce that Wonderland will be
                    located at the WPS Institute in Newton, MA. Wonderland is
                    free of charge to attend, so we want to make sure you can
                    make it out! If youâ€™re not from the Boston area, no problem.
                    Youâ€™ve got options.
Want more info about how to get to our venue?
A limited number of travel grants to partially cover flight
                    costs are available. Our registration form will ask for your
                    approximate location, and weâ€™ll use that information to get
                    back to you on what grants are available.
Find more info about flight grants here.
Boston is lucky to be a center of public transit. If you
                    live in the Northeast, you can likely get to Boston via bus
                    or train. With theHack Club Gas Fund,
                    weâ€™ll even reimburse some of the costs!
Amtrakhas a few
                    routes stopping in Bostonâ€™s South Station. Check out the
                    Amtrak site for more information.
If youâ€™d like to take a bus, check out services likeOurbusorFlixbusfor
                    affordable bus service to Boston.
If youâ€™re driving to Boston, weâ€™ll reimburse gas too! Using
                    theHack Club Gas Fund,
                    weâ€™ll cover the mileage you cover. Fill out the form on the
                    gas fund site to get details about reimbursement.
If you have any more questions, reach out on#wonderlandon theHack Club Slack,
                    or shoot us an email atwonderland@hackclub.com.
If you're eighteen or under, yes! If you're over 18 but
                        still in high school, shoot us an email atwonderland@hackclub.com.
Hackathons are for everybody!
A hackathon is an event where people can get together
                        and create! Don't worry, we're not doing any computer
                        hacking. Wonderland isnâ€™t like your typical hackathon,
                        though. Youâ€™re not required to do any coding at
                        Wonderland.
We welcome hackers from all backgrounds and skill
                        levels. All you need is the attitude to make something!
                        Wonderland is a place for beginners and experienced
                        makers alike!
Nothing! Weâ€™ll have meals, snacks, and beverages onsite
                        at the event, as well as swag and fun mini-events. We
                        also have a limited number of travel stipends for
                        students who need help getting to Boston. Check out the
                        Travel section for more details.
Your laptop, chargers, toiletries, sleeping bags, a
                        refillable water bottle, and the spirit of an explorer!
On the night of the event we will have a designated
                        gender-seperated and supervised sleeping area in the
                        venue with lowlights and minimal sound for you to rest.
                        Make sure to bring a sleeping bag!
No! Unlike most hackathons, youâ€™ll be placed into a team
                        ahead of time. Weâ€™ll assemble groups we anticipate will
                        work well together, and youâ€™ll get to know each other
                        throughout the weekend. Donâ€™t worry, you wonâ€™t be
                        evaluated based on your experience. Using our patented
                        team-maker formula 9000â„¢ï¸, weâ€™ll find teams with vibes
                        that match!
Reach out to us! Weâ€™re happy to talk to them. Wonderland
                        will be supervised by a background checked staff and
                        overseen by 24/7 security staff. Tell them to email us
                        atwonderland@hackclub.com, and weâ€™ll be happy to answer any questions!
They can also check out our Parents FAQ for some
                            common questions.
Reach out on#wonderlandon theHack Club Slack,
                    or email uswonderland@hackclub.com. We're always ready to answer all your questions!

title: Say Cheese!
content:
storage is too cheap nowadays. why not make it convenient instead?
build a program
fit it in a QR code
profit???
any program inside a qr code! this is platform agnostic, which means your program can run on x64 Linux, ARM Windows, or a Nintendo DS. as long as it's small enough to fit in a qr code, it counts!
start by checking the#saycheeseon slack for the FAQ and to chat with others working on similar projects! after that, read through the tutorial and scan the gallery to get an overview of what a project might look like.
size optimization is the real challenge here! there are a few ways you can fit a program this small into a qr code, but the best ways are programming in an assembly language (any assembly language counts), or
                            creating a webpage in HTML+JS.

title: Contribute to Hack Club
content:
A list of activeHack Clubopen source repositories onGitHub
Hack Club is anonprofit network of high school coding clubs and makers around the
          world. The Hack Club community hasover 250 open source repositories, many
        of which are being actively developed every day. What makes these
        repositories open source is that they areeditable by the public, which encourages
        you, the Hack Club community, to come together and collaborate on code
        socially.
Transparency is a core value of Hack Club, and code is not the only
        thing we open source.Check out our finances, workshops, and more.
Wewelcome and encourage your contributions,
        and we look forward to seeing the things you create!
Looking to contribute but don't know how?We have you covered!
Use your web inspector to hack your way through a series of
                  challenges.
If you'renew here, scroll down for steps to
          get started!
Note: This guide assumes you have aGitHubaccount,gitset up on your machine, and atext editorfor editing the code.
This document contains a set of guidelines which any contributions
              to any Hack Club repository must follow.
Contributions can happen in a lot of ways. Addingissues, creatingpull requests,
              andreviewingexisting pull requests are a few of those ways.
A fork is a copy of a repository that you manage. Forks let you
              make changes to a project without affecting the original code. You
              can create this copy by clicking on the "Fork" button at the top
              right of the repository page.
Cloning a repository is how you download the repository's code to
              your computer. You can clone the repository by clicking the green
              "Code" button on the repository page.
Pull requests are how you suggest your code edits! The maintainers
              of the repository may comment on your pull request, ask for
              changes, or approve it right away and merge it in.
Congratulations, you're now anopen source contributor!
Hack Clubis a nonprofit network of high school coding clubs and makers around
            the world. We are so happy to have you!
Weâ€™ve got a 24/7 Slack chatroom of 25k+ teenagers learning to
                code & building amazing projects, & youâ€™ll fit right in.
GitHub is a development platform where people collaborate on
                code. This is where we can find and edit each others code.
Pull requests are the way we edit each others code. Follow the
                link above for an interactive demonstation on how to make a pull
                request!
As a Hack Clubber, you are always learning and building things.
                Scrapbook allows you to share updates on the things you're doing
                with the rest of the Hack Club community.
Once you feel ready, you can start to contribute to other open
                source projects!

If you are unable to drive to a hackathon, we can reimburse the equivalent amount of miles for a bus/train ticket at a flat rate of10 cents a mile!

Join the club
And we've got the best collection anywhere in the universeâ„¢. Anyone who sends us a dino drawing will earn the dinoisseur badge, as well as get an exclusive emoji on Slack.
Hack Club stores all its code on GitHub, includingthisÂ website,and the best way to make changes (such as adding a dinosaur) is by submitting a pull request on GitHub.
The first step is to make our dino. Don't worry about setupâ€”we've included a full dino-drawing-a-tron below for you to use. Just click "next" and make that dino! You're also free to use a photo.
If you already know how to submit PRs to the dino repo, go ahead andread this.
Finish and save your dino drawing to continue
Now you'll need permission to edit the dinos repo. We've just sent you an invite, and depending on your settings, it will be auto-accepted or you'll need toaccept it here. If it doesn't show up there, check your email.
Go to the next step once you've accepted your invite.
âœ¨â­ï¸âœ¨
Now go tohttps://github.com/hackclub/dinosaursand click â€œstarâ€. This bookmarks the repository in GitHub.
Afterwards, tab back to this page to continue.
Create Branch: drawing-dino
Find and click the dropdown â€œBranch: main â–¼â€.
Type in
Click â€œCreate branch:YOUR-DINO-NAMEâ€
Upload your masterpiece
Click â€œAdd fileâ€ and add your dino image
Below â€œCommit changesâ€, type this into the first text box:
Then clickCOMMIT CHANGES
Warning:Do notclick the green button that says "Create pull request" just yetâ€“ we'll get there in a couple more steps.
Find README.md
Scroll through the list of files & find â€œREADME.mdâ€.
To edit the file, click it & click theicon.
Add your dino in the README.md
Add the following lines to the bottom of the file:
Below â€œCommit changesâ€, type
Then clickCOMMIT CHANGES
Create a PR
Go back tohttps://github.com/hackclub/dinosaursand clickCompare & pull request.
Then clickCreate pull request
Orpheus says:â€œThat's all for now folks!â€

title: A Home for High School Hackers â€“ Hack Club
content:
We are55,056teen hackersteen hackersfrom around the world who code together
Every day, thousands of HackÂ Clubbers gather online and in-person to make things with code. Whether youâ€™re a beginner programmer or have years of experience, thereâ€™s a place for you at HackÂ Club. Read about ourhacker ethic.
Connect with other teenage codersHave a coding question? Looking for project feedback? Youâ€™ll find hundreds of fabulous people to talk to in our globalSlack(like Discord), active at all hours.
Build open source learning toolsWe build large open source projects together (3k+Â PRs a year) like this website, a game engine, daily streak system, and more!
Gather IRL with other makersMeet other HackÂ Clubbers in your community to build together at one of the 400+HackÂ Clubsandhigh school hackathons.
We gather both online and in-person to share our love of code and make things together!
Build personal projects. Get free stuff.Oct 30 - Jan 31
HACK CLUB'S BEGINNER FRIENDLY GAME JAM100+ CITIES NOV 23-24
Pacific Crest TrailJuly 12-19
30 Hack Clubbers went on a 7 day hike along the Pacific Crest Trail supplied by only the technical equipment that they built.
Coding doesnâ€™t have to be a solitary activity. At HackÂ Club, we make remarkable things together, and in our Slack youâ€™ll find awesome people to hang out with too. Code together, find your programming community, dream up something wild, or just #lounge.
Occasionally we invite someone we really want to speak to (like Sal Khan, George Hotz, and Lady Ada) and host anAMAwith them.
In collaboration with engineers on the HackÂ Club team, Hack Clubbers build learning tools for each other. Get involved with these projects by building something with our tools or contribute to the tools themselves.
Draw, make music, and craft games in our web-based JavaScript game editor, which has been used by 7k+ makers around the world.
0projects built
Circuit boards are magical. You design one, we'll print it. Completely for free! Get a $100 grant to fuel the creation of your dream project with OnBoard.
Blot is an open source drawing machine and online editor, designed to be a fun and beginner friendly introduction to digital fabrication and generative art.
SineRider is a game about love and graphing, powered by teenage hackers of all kinds: artists, musicians, programmers, storytellersâ€¦ so if thatâ€™s you, come join us! We can always use help keeping everything up to date and running smoothly.
Join the other743teenagers with Sprigs!
Play your own Sprig games on this console, which you can assemble and disassemble. Each kit includes parts needed for getting started with hardware engineering and embedded systems programming.
100+ community-contributed, self-guided coding tutorials and ideas. Learn to code by building, one project at a time.
Thousands of Hack Clubbers organize and participate in hackathons and after school coding clubs.
Join or start a HackÂ Club and be part of a network of high quality coding clubs where you learn to code entirely through building things.
You can start with no experience and build and ship a project every meeting.
We support the largest network of high school hackathons in the world. From an online community of organizers to free stickers and more!
Become a 501(c)3 nonprofit and join 700+ teams using HCB to run world-class events.
This platform is built and maintained by the HackÂ Club team.
We've got a lot going on - Letâ€™s recap
Connect with other technical teenagers on Slack and hack on things together.
Weâ€™re currently building a game engine, daily streak system, graphing game, and more!
Build an in-person community of high school hackers, and weâ€™re here to help.
We'll send you an email no more than once a month, when we work on something cool for you. Check out ourprevious issues.
Â©2025HackÂ Club. 501(c)(3) nonprofit (EIN: 81-2908499)

title: Mira Costa Hack Club
content:
A place for
Vice President
I am a senior at Mira Costa High School and I love to surf and skate.
Co-Founder, President
Hello, I'm Winston, a current sophomore at Mira Costa High School. Passionate about spreading computer science and cybersecurity education to the world, I co-founded Mathisi-fyâ€”a 501(c)(3) non-profit sponsored by Google, HyperX, MalwareBytes, and moreâ€”that seeks to empower underrepresented students around the world with STEM education.
Co-Founder, Co-President
Dylan is currently a senior attending Mira Costa High School. He's an active CTF player and founded RGBsec, the U.S.'s #1 ranked H.S. cybersecurity team. He was awarded Grand Prize Winner of Google Code-in 2019 and First Place at the National Congressional App Challenge. Dylan is a researcher at the U.S. Air Force Research Laboratory working on a project on high-powered microwave (HPM) devices using AFRL's Improved Concurrent Electromagnetic Particle-in-Cell (ICEPIC) with various genetic optimization algorithms. Dylan is also captain of 6.1one, Costa's top CyberPatriot team.
The Mira Costa Hack Club is a club lead by students that aim to teach high schoolers about technology with a hands on, project based learning approach. The Mira Costa Hack Club encourages self teaching of new technologies, and self directed projects. All levels are welcome, but most of our workshops will be tailored towards intermediate and beginner levels. We are also a chapter of a non-profit organization called Hack Club that supports us with advice, technical assistance, workshops, and swag.
By the word "hacking" we mean "a usually creatively improvised solution to a computer hardware or programming problem or limitation" -Merriam Webster. We will not break any systems or do anything illegal.

title: Happy birthday Christina!
content:
Happy Birthday Christina!
I want to thank you for being such a great mentor and colleague this
      summer. Youâ€™ve guided and supported me throughout my time working at Hack
      Club which has been the greatest experience. Youâ€™re someone I look up to
      also for your work and influence outside of Hack Club. Thank you so much
      for the patience, advice, and encouragement that youâ€™ve given me.
Dina
Happy birthday Christina!
Since you joined in February, Hack Club started to never be the same. The
      relentlessness, kindness, and thoughtful leadership you've brought to Hack
      Club make us better every day.
I can't think of a better person to be running this org with. I'm so glad
      to have you as a teammate and as a friend.
- Zach
Happy Birthday Christina! I feel so fortunate that I met you this summer.
      You have been a great role model to me and Iâ€™m forever grateful. I hope
      this year is the best year yet.
by Fischler
Hey Christina!
When Zach called me a while ago to talk about bringing you onto the team,
      I was psyched. Your track record as a professional spoke for itself, you
      had amazing potential to bring some much needed direction to the team, and
      you sounded like a perfect fit. You have doneâ€” and beenâ€”all of that and
      moe. May your birthday today be as exceptional as you are, Iâ€™m excited to
     work together
     more in the future.
Michael
Christina,
It's truly been a fantastic time working with you at Hack Club over the past few months. I've become a better writer, thinker, and person thanks to you & I hope we get to work together again in the future.
Have a very happy birthday!
- Theo
Happy Birthday Christina! I am so honored that I've been able to work with you this past Summer and empower over 370 students in technology. Your willingness to help others around you has helped me see the power of community in STEM and I'm grateful to have you as a role model to look up to. Thank you so much for always believing in me and dedicating your time to hearing about an idea I came up with on a whim. I'm so excited to see you take to Hack Club to even greater heights and work with you in the future! I hope you have a great day :)
Shivali Gulati
Happy birthday Christina!
I wassoooexcited when I first heard you were joining Hack Club
      because it meant we were finally getting our first teammate who's a real
      adult and professional!
I vividly remember the first time I met you, in early March, when you came
      to New Haven and chatted with the clubs team about the long-term future of
      Hack Club. That conversation made me incredibly excited for the future of
      Hack Club, both long-term and while I'm working here. I continue to be
      amazed by what you bring to Hack Club.
Plus, if it weren't for you, I wouldn't have visited the magical land of
      Vermont, which I now believe is an undiscovered gem of the world!Stay awesome,Matthew âœ¨
Woot woot!! Happy Birthday Christina!!!
Hey!! Christina, you are an inspiration to so many people! Your 
      previous work in the Middle East is really fascinating, it's something
      that is quite foreign to many of us so it's really interesting hearing 
      stories about it. You've always been super kind to me and it was great 
      to do stuff with you over the summer! Keep going with the coding, it's 
      really cool! Have a great rest of your birthday!!
- Sam P
Wow it's your birthday!
Christina, you have been a truly awesome person to get to know/work with.
      Your tenacity, kind-hartedness, and just Hack Club mom personality (ğŸ˜›)
      just highlights what a great person you are. You may be the COO of Hack Club
      and that's super important but you have been an even better counsel at times
      when I've needed it most.
Hack Club and the community is lucky to have you and I wish the bestest birthday
      in the world. âœ¨
Chaleb
Christinaâ€”itâ€™s been such a joy working with you this year at HackÂ Club. One of my favorite parts of anybody joining is seeing what they do no one else could or wouldâ€™ve made happenâ€¦fromElon Muskâ€™s donationto ourjust incredible AMAsto ourVIP newsletters, itâ€™s been so amazing to see everything youâ€™ve brought to the team.
Personally, youâ€™ve also just been a joy to be around, from our Philo campfire to editing newsletters together. I never wouldâ€™ve even been to Vermont without you either, much less got to hang out for two remarkable months.
Iâ€™m so glad to have you here at Hack Club, & thanks so much for everything you do. Happy birthday
Christina, you are one of the most interesting, kind, and hardworking people I know. 
 It is an absolite blast to work with you and even just talk to you. 
 War journalist?? Best Selling Author?? Fundraising Goddess?? The Fuller Project? 
The work you do is incredible, and you are directly benefitting so many student's lives. Keep doing you, you're incredible, happy birthday :)

amogh
Wow it's your birthday!
Chrsistina, you have been a truly awesome person to get to know/work with.

Create an issue byfilling out the form. We will then review it and ad it toLINKS.txt.
